title: Hackworth v. Greenville County
description: The Hackworths appeal the circuit court's grant of summary judgment on their action seeking recovery of $152,016 seized by the Greenville County Sheriff's Department.  Mr. Hackworth signed a forfeiture agreement acknowledging the money was gambling proceeds and would be forfeited as part of a plea agreement.  This Court affirmed the circuit court's holding that the Hackworths failed to assert their claims within the two-year statute of limitations.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Edman Hackworth and Debbie Kay Hackworth, Appellants,
v.
Greenville County and Greenville County Sheriff's Department, Respondents.
      
    
  

__________
Appeal From Greenville County
Â D. Garrison Hill, Circuit Court Judge
__________
Opinion No.Â  4174
Heard September 13, 2006 â€“ Filed November 6, 2006
__________
AFFIRMED
__________

  
    
      
William Henry Thomas, of Greenville, for Appellants.
Russell W. Harter, Jr., of Greenville, for Respondents.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.: Edman and Debbie Hackworth appeal the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of Greenville County and the Greenville County Sheriffâ€™s Department.Â  The Hackworths seek to recover $152,016 seized during the sheriff departmentâ€™s investigation into their alleged illegal gambling.
FACTS
During 1999, the Greenville County Sheriffâ€™s Department investigated Edman and Debbie Hackworth for suspected gambling activity.Â  The sheriffâ€™s department executed search warrants on the Hackworthâ€™s home, one of their businesses, and two safety deposit boxes. Â These searches yielded evidence of the Hackworthâ€™s gambling, including inter alia over $160,000 in cash, computers, phones, a paper shredder, and parlay cards.Â  On September 7, 1999, Edman and Debbie were arrested on charges of â€œbetting, pool-setting, bookmaking and the like,â€ and Edman was also charged with â€œsetting up a lottery.â€ 
Ultimately, Edman reached a plea agreement with the sheriffâ€™s department whereby he would forfeit $152,016 of the seized cash and plea guilty to the lesser charge of â€œadventure in the lotteriesâ€ and pay a $125 fine. Â In exchange, all of the original charges against Debbie and Edman were nol prossed and approximately $14,000 was returned to them.Â  On September 30, 1999, Edman signed a document entitled â€œconsent forfeiture of monies derived from gambling.â€Â  This document stated that it was the partiesâ€™ desire to enter into a compromise settlement to avoid litigation, and that Edman voluntarily relinquished his right to $152,016 â€œpursuant to Â§ 16-19-80, Code of Laws of South Carolina (1976), as amended.â€[1]Â  Although the document had signature blocks for Edman, an assistant solicitor, a sheriffâ€™s deputy, and a circuit court judge, only Edman signed the document. 
Edman pled guilty to â€œadventure in the lotteriesâ€ and paid the $125 fine.Â  All three of the original charges against Edman and Debbie were nol prossed. 
The Hackworths claimed the $152,016 forfeiture as a deduction from their federal income tax for 1999.Â  The Internal Revenue Service denied this deduction, and the federal tax court affirmed the denial at the resulting tax trial.Â  Two sheriffâ€™s department deputies served as witnesses at the Hackworthâ€™s tax trial. 
The Hackworths claimed that during the tax trial they discovered that a judge did not sign the consent to forfeiture.Â  As a result, on April 7, 2004, they initiated the present action against the sheriffâ€™s department seeking to recover the $152,016. Â In the present civil action, the Hackworths assert unlawful seizure, conversion by the sheriffâ€™s department, and creation of a constructive trust to protect the money.Â  The circuit court heard oral arguments and granted the sheriffâ€™s departmentâ€™s motion for summary judgment based on the statute of limitations.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  White v. J.M. Brown Amusement Co., 360 S.C. 366, 601 S.E.2d 342 (2004).Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all inferences which can reasonably be drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Medical Univ. of South Carolina v. Arnaud, 360 S.C. 615, 602 S.E.2d 747 (2004).Â  â€œ[W]hen plain, palpable, and indisputable facts exist on which reasonable minds cannot differ, summary judgment should be granted.â€Â  Hedgepath v. American Tel. & Tel. Co., 348 S.C. 340, 355, 559 S.E.2d 327, 336 (Ct. App. 2001).
DISCUSSION
The Hackworths argue that the trial court erred in dismissing their claim on a motion for summary judgment and that the court incorrectly interpreted the requirements of civil forfeiture pursuant to South Carolina Code Ann. Section 16-19-80 (1976)Â  by disregarding due process rights to a hearing.Â  We disagree.
The court granted summary judgment based on the statute of limitations.Â  For claims filed under the Tort Claims Act, the statute of limitations is two years after the loss was or should have been discovered.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-110 (2005).Â  The date on which discovery of the cause of action should have been made is an objective, rather than subjective, question.Â  Kreutner v. David, 320 S.C. 283, 285, 465 S.E.2d 88, 90 (1995).Â  

In other words, whether the particular plaintiff actually knew he had a claim is not the test.Â  Rather, courts must decide whether the circumstances of the case would put a person of common knowledge and experience on notice that some right of his has been invaded, or that some claim against another party might exist.Â  

Young v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corrections, 333 S.C. 714, 719, 511 S.E.2d 413, 416 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
On September 30, 1999, the Hackworths either knew or should have known they lost their ownership interest in the $152,016 when Edman signed the consent to forfeiture.Â  If the Hackworths thought their property was improperly seized and retained, they should have initiated an action before September 30, 2001.Â  
However, the Hackworths claim the statute of limitations should not run until after their federal tax case was resolved because the money was evidence at that time, and they could not get it back while the case was pending.Â  They assert the fact that two sheriffâ€™s deputies testified for the IRS gives them reason to believe the cash could have been used as evidence during trial. The money was never used in any of the Hackworthâ€™s court appearances.
There is no evidence in the record to support the Hackworthâ€™s position.Â  The only evidence indicating the Hackworths either knew or should have known that the sheriffâ€™s department claimed ownership interest in the money is the â€œconsent to forfeitureâ€ document and the testimony that the Hackworths claimed a deduction on their 1999 tax return for the exact amount of the forfeiture.Â  There is no testimony to suggest the cash was retained as sheriffâ€™s department property on any date other than September 30, 1999, the date of the forfeiture.Â  Therefore, the statute of limitations began to run on that date.
The Hackworths also argue that due process requires judicial approval of the forfeiture.Â  Citing United States v. Minor, 228 F.3d 352 (4th Cir. 2000) and United States v. Aguirre, 264 F.3d 1195 (10th Cir. 2001), the Hackworths contend that no forfeiture occurred because there was not a forfeiture hearing.Â  However, these federal cases are distinguishable because Edman consented to forfeit the cash and thus had knowledge of the forfeiture when it occurred, whereas the forfeitures in the federal cases were involuntary and the hearing served as notice to the defendants.Â  Even if due process requires such a hearing, we need not address this claim because the Hackworths neglected to demand such a hearing and did not challenge the voluntary forfeiture within the two-year statute of limitations.Â  In fact, the Hackworths failed to assert their claims for over four and one half years.Â  
Notably, Edman agreed to forfeit his gambling proceeds in exchange for his plea to a lesser charge, all charges against him and his wife being nol prossed, and the return of $14,000.Â  Edman and Debbie enjoyed the full benefit of that agreement and cannot now bring suit to recover the money.Â  
The Hackworths failed to provide evidence that would tend to support their position.Â  All of the evidence presented to the trial judge showed the Hackworths were aware of the moneyâ€™s forfeiture.Â  Therefore, the trial court was justified in granting summary judgment.
Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s decision is
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, Â and BEATTY, JJ., concur. 

[1] South Carolina Code Ann. Â§16-19-80 (2005) states â€œ[a]ll and every sum or sums of money staked, betted or pending on the event of any such game or games as aforesaid are hereby declared to be forfeited.â€Â  The statute does not provide a process for law enforcement to follow with forfeited money.

title: Brannon v. Palmetto Bank
description: This Court reversed the circuit court finding Palmetto Bank was entitled to a directed verdict on the Brannons' causes of action for breach of contract and conversion.  The mortgage contract between Palmetto Bank and the Brannons allowed Palmetto Bank to use insurance proceeds to pay off the mortgage debt.  Since Palmetto Bank had a legal right use the insurance proceeds to set-off the Brannons' mortgage debt, Palmetto Bank cannont be held liable for conversion of those funds.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Robert S. Brannon and Kimberly C. Brannon, Respondents,
v.
The Palmetto Bank and Howard Barnard, Defendants,
        Of whom The Palmetto Bank is the Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4175
Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed November 6, 2006

REVERSED


  
    
      
F. Marion Hughes, Langdon Cheves, III and Seann Gray Tzouvelekas, all of Greenville, for Appellant.
H. Michael Spivey, of Mauldin, for Respondents.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.:Â  On appeal, Palmetto Bank contends the trial court erred in refusing to direct a verdict in its favor on Robert and Kimberly Brannonâ€™s causes of action for breach of contract and conversion.Â  In the alternative, Palmetto Bank contends the trial court erred in directing a verdict against Palmetto Bank on the Brannonsâ€™ breach of contract claim rather than submitting the issue to the jury.Â  Additionally, Palmetto Bank argues the trial court erred in allowing the jury to consider evidence of speculative damages.Â Â  We reverse.Â  
FACTS
On January 22, 2002, the Brannons bought a house out of foreclosure from Palmetto Bank.Â  Two closings occurred in order to finalize this transaction.Â  The first closing was on a 90-day note for the purpose of giving the Brannons time to sell their former house.Â  The closing held on January 22, 2002, was to refinance the original 90-day note for $155,000.00 plus $5,000.00 in interest charged during the 90-day period by Palmetto Bank.Â  The Brannonsâ€™ monetary obligation to Palmetto Bank was secured by a mortgage lien on the residence being purchased.Â  
The mortgage agreement required the Brannons to keep the house insured for its full insurable value and required the insurance be payable to Palmetto Bank as a loss payee.Â  Pursuant to the mortgage, the Brannons also assigned to Palmetto Bank â€œthe right to collect and receive any indemnity payment otherwise owed to [the Brannons] upon any policy of insurance insuring any portion of the property, regardless of whether [Palmetto Bank] is named in such policy as a person entitled to collect upon the same.â€Â  
On February 19, 2002, the Brannonsâ€™ home was destroyed by fire.Â  An insurance check was issued by the carrier for $185,850.00 and was made payable to the Brannons, Palmetto Bank, and the builders replacing the Brannonsâ€™ home.Â  Mrs. Brannon took the check to Palmetto Bank, which advised her to open a general deposit account into which most of the insurance proceeds were deposited.Â  Palmetto Bank issued a check to Mrs. Brannon for $25,000 so she could pay her builders.Â  
On the same day the general deposit account was opened, a hold was placed on the account so that the insurance proceeds could not be withdrawn.Â  Two days later, Palmetto Bank withdrew the sum of $160,257.78 from the deposit account and paid off the mortgage debt.Â  Mrs. Brannon later went to Palmetto Bank to withdraw more money in order to pay her builders when she discovered the mortgage had been paid off and the deposit account was virtually empty.Â  The Brannons then had to receive new financing for the home they were building.Â  Apparently, the Brannons had a history of bad credit which created problems with the financing.Â  Eventually they received financing, but at a much higher interest rate than what they had with the previous mortgage.Â  When the Brannons learned that Palmetto Bank had used the deposit account to satisfy the mortgage debt, this litigation ensued.Â  
At trial, testimony showed the Brannons were aware there was a possibility that the insurance proceeds could be used to pay off the mortgage debt.Â  Palmetto Bank explained that this procedure is meant to be beneficial for both the lender and the borrower.Â  It is beneficial to the borrower because when the existing loan gets paid off, the borrower under the new construction loan pays interest only on the amount that has been advanced rather than the full principal amount of the existing loan.Â  It is beneficial to the lender because, after the fire has destroyed the house, the lenderâ€™s only collateral is the vacant lot.Â  
The trial court found, as a matter of law, Palmetto Bank was liable to the Brannons for breach of contract.Â  The determination of damages owed on the breach of contract claim and the liability and damages owed on the conversion claim were submitted to the jury.Â  Subsequently, the jury found Palmetto Bank liable on the conversion cause of action and awarded damages in the amount of $133,000.Â  Palmetto Bank filed motions seeking a judgment notwithstanding the verdict or, in the alternative, a new trial, which were denied.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When ruling on directed verdict or JNOV motions, the trial court must view the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Sabb v. S.C. State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 427, 567 S.E.2d 231, 236 (2002).Â  If the evidence as a whole is susceptible to more than one reasonable inference, a jury issue is created and the motion should be denied.Â  Adams v. G.J. Creel & Sons, Inc., 320 S.C. 274, 277, 465 S.E.2d 84, 85 (1995); Bailey v. Segars, 346 S.C. 359, 365, 550 S.E.2d 910, 913 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  However, this rule does not authorize submission of speculative, theoretical, and hypothetical views to the jury.Â  Hanahan v. Simpson, 326 S.C. 140, 149, 485 S.E.2d 903, 908 (1997).Â  In reviewing a grant of a directed verdict, the appellate court should not ignore facts unfavorable to the opposing party.Â  Collins v. Bisson Moving & Storage, Inc., 332 S.C. 290, 295-96, 504 S.E.2d 347, 350 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  In essence, the court must determine whether a verdict for the opposing party â€œwould be reasonably possible under the facts as liberally construed in his favor.â€Â  Harvey v. Strickland, 350 S.C. 303, 309, 566 S.E.2d 529, 532 (2002).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Directed Verdict on Breach of Contract (Mortgage and Deposit Agreement) Cause of Action 
Palmetto Bank contends the trial court erred in failing to direct a verdict in its favor on the Brannonsâ€™ breach of contract cause of action.Â  In the alternative, Palmetto Bank asserts it was error to direct a verdict in favor of the Brannons and in failing to submit the issue to the jury.Â  We agree the court erred in not directing a verdict for Palmetto Bank on the breach of contract cause of action.Â  
Paragraph 3 of the mortgage agreement gives Palmetto Bank four options in dealing with the insurance proceeds:Â  

Any indemnity payment received by [Palmetto Bank] from any such policy of insurance may, at the option of [Palmetto Bank], (i) be applied by [Palmetto Bank] to payment of any sum secured by this Mortgage in such order as [Palmetto Bank] may determine or (ii) be applied in a manner determined by [Palmetto Bank] to the replacement, repair or restoration of the portion of the Property damaged or destroyed or (iii) be released to [the Brannons] upon such conditions as [Palmetto Bank] may determine or (iv) be used for any combination of the foregoing purposes.Â  

The trial court found as a matter of law that Palmetto Bankâ€™s deposit of a portion of the insurance proceeds into the deposit account constituted an unconditional â€œreleaseâ€ of those proceeds under paragraph 3(iii) of the Mortgage.Â  The trial court further found:Â  (1) once Palmetto Bank had chosen this option under paragraph 3(iii), it had no right of set-off against the deposit account to satisfy the Mortgage debt; and (2) in setting off against the deposit account, Palmetto Bank became liable to the Brannons as a matter of law for breach of contract.Â  
The Brannons claim Palmetto Bank unconditionally released the insurance proceeds to them and cannot now revoke the release.Â  â€œReleaseâ€ is defined as â€œthe act of giving up a right or claim to the person against whom it could have been enforced.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 1292 (7th ed. 1999).Â  Â Â While it is true Palmetto Bank may have released a portion of the insurance proceeds to the Brannons, the remaining money was placed in a general deposit account.Â  The agreement pertaining to the deposit account contained a paragraph entitled â€œSet-Offâ€ which gave Palmetto Bank the specific right, without prior notice to the Brannons, to â€œset-off the funds in this account against any due and payable debt owed . . . .â€Â  By placing the funds into a deposit account with a set-off provision, Palmetto Bank was not releasing its right or claim to the insurance proceeds.Â  Because both parties retained control over the proceeds placed in the deposit account, the release cannot be seen as absolute.Â  To come to the conclusion of the trial court, a release must have been a complete and total release.Â Â  
Option (iv) of the mortgage agreement gave Palmetto Bank the ability to choose any of the other three options in any combination it wished.Â  Palmetto Bank chose to release a portion of the proceeds and pay off the mortgage with the remainder.Â  Pursuant to the mortgage agreement, Palmetto Bank was within its rights to do so.Â  See MGC Mgmt. of Charleston, Inc. v. Kinghorn Ins. Agency, 336 S.C. 542, 548, 520 S.E.2d 820, 823 (Ct. App. 1999) (stating court must construe contract in a way â€œwhich will give effect to the whole instrument and each of its various partsâ€).Â  Accordingly, the trial court erred in failing to direct a verdict in Palmetto Bankâ€™s favor concerning the breach of contract issue.[1]Â  
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Directed Verdict on Conversion Cause of Action 
Palmetto Bank contends the trial court erred in failing to direct a verdict in its favor on the Brannonsâ€™ conversion cause of action.Â  We agree. 
â€œConversion is the unauthorized assumption and exercise of the right of ownership over goods or personal chattels belonging to another, to the alteration of the condition or the exclusion of the ownerâ€™s rights.â€Â  Crane v. Citicorp Natâ€™l Servs., Inc., 313 S.C. 70, 73, 437 S.E.2d 50, 52 (1993).Â  â€œConversion may arise by some illegal use or misuse, or by illegal detention of anotherâ€™s personal property.â€Â  Regions Bank v. Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 667, 582 S.E.2d 432, 442 (Ct. App. 2003). â€œConversion is a wrongful act which emanates by either a wrongful taking or wrongful detention.â€ Â Id.
As a matter of law, Palmetto Bank is not liable for conversion of the insurance proceeds because its use of the funds was not an unauthorized taking as Palmetto Bank had a legal right to the funds.Â  In fact, the case of Richardsonâ€™s Rests., Inc. v. The Natâ€™l Bank of South Carolina, 304 S.C. 289, 294, 403 S.E.2d 669, 672 (Ct. App. 1991), states that a bank cannot be liable for conversion of funds deposited into a payroll account because the deposits â€œbecome part of the [b]ankâ€™s general account against which [the depositorâ€™s] account received a credit.â€Â  This Court went on the say this is true, â€œeven though [the depositor] intended to use the account for a particular purpose.â€Â  Id. at 295, 304 S.E.2d at 672. Â This position is only bolstered by the right of set-off pursuant to the deposit agreement, as discussed above.Â  Accordingly, the trial court erred in failing to direct a verdict in favor of Palmetto Bank on the issue of conversion. 
III.Â Â Â  Evidence of Speculative Damages 
Palmetto Bank contends the trial court erred in allowing the jury to consider evidence of speculative damages.Â  Because we reverse on the two previous issues, we need not reach the issue of speculative damages.Â  See 
Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (An appellate court need not address remaining issues when disposition of prior issue is dispositive.).
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
REVERSED. [2]
GOOLSBY, Â and BEATTY, JJ., concur. 

[1] Palmetto Bank also contends the trial court erred in stating Palmetto Bank waived its right to apply the insurance proceeds to the outstanding mortgage debt by placing the funds in a deposit account.Â  However, the trial court did not make the finding Palmetto Bank waived its rights to the insurance proceeds.Â  However, had the trial court come to such a conclusion, it would have been in error.Â  â€œWaiver is the voluntary and intentional relinquishment of a known right.â€Â  Mailsource, LLC v. M.A. Bailey & Assocs., Inc., 356 S.C. 370, 375, 588 S.E.2d 639, 641 (Ct. App. 2003).Â Â  Palmetto Bankâ€™s action did not constitute a waiver as there was clearly no intent on its part to relinquish its rights to the insurance proceeds.Â Â  
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: SC Farm Bureau  v. Dawsey
description: The court affirms the denial of coverage, based on the specific wording of an insurance policy exclusion, for an unintentional injury resulting from an intentional act.
text:
SC Farm Bureau v. Dawsey


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
South Carolina Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company,
Respondent,
v.
David R. Dawsey, Sr. and David R. Dawsey, Jr., Defendants, 
of whom David R. Dawsey, Jr. is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Mikell R. Scarborough, Master In Equity

Opinion No. 4176
Submitted October 1, 2006 â€“ Filed November 6, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James K. Holmes, of Charleston, for Appellant.Â  
Robert J. Thomas, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  South Carolina Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company filed this declaratory judgment action against David R. Dawsey, Sr. (father) and David R. Dawsey, Jr. (son) seeking a determination regarding coverage under a homeownerâ€™s insurance policy.Â  The master in equity found the policy excluded coverage for injuries incurred by the son.Â  The son appeals.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
The parties stipulated to the underlying facts:Â  The father was insured under a Farm Bureau homeownerâ€™s policy.Â  On February 22, 2002, the son drove to the fatherâ€™s home in North Charleston.Â  â€œ[D]uring th[e] visit, there was some hostility.â€Â  The father fired his pistol three times at the tires on the sonâ€™s truck.Â  One of the bullets ricocheted off the driveway and hit the son in the jaw, inflicting substantial injury. Â The son filed a negligence action against the father.Â  The father did not answer the complaint and is in default.Â  Farm Bureau filed this declaratory judgment action.
The policy provides coverage for bodily injury caused by an occurrence but excludes coverage for injury â€œresulting from intentional acts or directions of you or any insured.Â  The expected or unexpected results or (sic) these acts or directions are not covered.â€Â  The master found the exclusion applied in this case and entered judgment for Farm Bureau.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Because declaratory judgment actions are neither legal nor equitable, the
standard of review depends on the nature of the underlying issues. Â Auto-Owners Ins. Co. v. Hamin, 368 S.C. 536, 540, 629 S.E.2d 683, 685 (Ct. App. 2006), petition for cert. filed, (S.C. June 16, 2006).Â  When the purpose of the underlying dispute is to determine whether coverage exists under an insurance policy, the action is one at law.Â  Id. Â In an action at law tried without a jury, the appellate court will not disturb the trial courtâ€™s findings of fact unless they are found to be without evidence that reasonably supports those findings. Â Id.Â  When an appeal involves stipulated or undisputed facts, an appellate court is free to determine if the trial court properly applied the law to the facts. Â In re Estate of Boynton, 355 S.C. 299, 301, 584 S.E.2d 154, 155 (Ct. App. 2003). Â In such a situation, the appellate court does not have to defer to the trial courtâ€™s findings. Â Id. at 301-02, 584 S.E.2d at 155.
LAW/ANALYSIS
The son argues the master erred in construing the policy to exclude coverage.Â  We disagree.Â  
Insurance policies are subject to the general rules of contract construction.Â  Century Indem. Co. v. Golden Hills Builders, Inc., 348 S.C. 559, 565, 561 S.E.2d 355, 358 (2002).Â  The court must give policy language its plain, ordinary, and popular meaning.Â  Id.Â  Although exclusions in a policy are construed against the insurer, insurers have the right to limit their liability and to impose conditions on their obligations provided they are not in contravention of public policy or a statutory prohibition.Â  B.L.G. Enters. v. First Fin. Ins. Co., 334 S.C. 529, 535-36, 514 S.E.2d 327, 330 (1999).Â  The court cannot torture the meaning of policy language to extend coverage not intended by the parties.Â  State Farm Fire & Cas. Co. v. Barrett, 340 S.C. 1, 8, 530 S.E.2d 132, 135 (Ct. App. 2000).
The son argues the South Carolina Supreme Courtâ€™s interpretation of the intentional acts exclusions in Miller v. Fidelity-Phoenix Insurance Co., 268 S.C. 72, 231 S.E.2d 701 (1977), and Vermont Mutual Insurance Co. v. Singleton, 316 S.C. 5, 446 S.E.2d 417 (1994), should have been applied in this case.Â  The insurance policies in Miller and Vermont Mutual contained language excluding coverage for damage intentionally caused by the insured.Â  The policies did not specifically exclude coverage for the unintentional consequences of intentional acts.Â  
The Miller court developed a two-prong test to analyze coverage under an exclusion such as that found in the Miller case.Â  To exclude coverage under the Miller test, the act causing the loss must have been intentional and the consequences must have been intended.Â  Miller, 268 S.C. at 75, 231 S.E.2d at 701 (providing coverage where a child set fire to a home for the excitement of seeing the fire trucks arrive but no intent to damage the home).Â  In Vermont Mutual, the court applied the Miller test, rejecting the insurerâ€™s argument to adopt a more â€œcontemporaryâ€ intentional act analysis.Â  316 S.C. at 7-8, 446 S.E.2d at 419 (providing coverage where a teenager acted in self-defense when he struck another teenager but did not intend the extensive eye injuries inflicted).
The son argues the policy language in this case excludes coverage for unexpected consequences but does not exclude coverage for unintentional consequences.Â  Thus, the son maintains, the second prong of the Miller test should still apply to provide coverage.Â  The son admits, however, that the terms â€œintendâ€ and â€œexpectâ€ are â€œoften defined synonymously.â€Â  To read the policy in the manner urged by the son would require us to rewrite the policy, rather than interpret it as written.Â  â€œThe judicial function of a court of law is to enforce an insurance contract as made by the parties, and not to rewrite or to distort, under the guise of judicial construction . . . .â€Â  Thompson v. Continental Ins. Cos., 291 S.C. 47, 49, 351 S.E.2d 904, 905 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  We agree with the master that the policy excludes coverage for the sonâ€™s injuries, which were unexpected consequences of the fatherâ€™s intentional act of shooting at the sonâ€™s tire.Â  Therefore, the order on appeal is 
 AFFIRMED.Â  
 HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE, J., concur.

[1]Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. Sosbee
description: Sosbee was convicted of assault with intent to commit criminal sexual conduct with a minor in the first degree and committing a lewd act upon a child.  He was sentenced to life without the possibility of parole and fifteen years, respectively.  He appeals, arguing the trial court erred in: (1) sentencing him to life without the possibility of parole; and (2) allowing the State to amend an indictment where it changed the nature of the offense.  We affirm.

        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster; Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh; Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott; Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville; for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  George Franklin Sosbee, Jr., was convicted of assault with intent to commit criminal sexual conduct with a minor in the first degree and committing a lewd act upon a child.Â  He was sentenced to life without the possibility of parole and fifteen years imprisonment, respectively.Â  He appeals, arguing the trial court erred in: (1) sentencing him to life without the possibility of parole; and (2) allowing the State to amend an indictment where it changed the nature of the offense.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In 2003, Sosbee lived with the grandmother of an eight-year-old girl (the victim).Â  In September or October of that year, the victim told her mother and another female adult that a few months prior, Sosbee touched her in her private parts with his hand and tongue and threatened to put her grandparents and aunts in jail if she told anyone.Â  The victim was examined by a physician, but there were no signs of injury.Â  Sosbee was charged with committing a lewd act on a minor and criminal sexual conduct with a minor, first degree.Â  Because Sosbee had a prior conviction for criminal sexual conduct, second degree, the State served notice that it intended to seek a sentence of life without the possibility of parole.Â  
At trial, the victim testified Sosbee touched her on her privates with his hand and tongue.Â  On cross-examination, the victim also stated that all of the touching occurred while she was clothed.Â  At the end of the Stateâ€™s case, Sosbee moved for a directed verdict as to both charges, arguing there was no evidence of penetration and any alleged touching could not meet the statutory definition of sexual battery because the victim was wearing clothing and there was no skin-to-skin contact. Â The State moved to amend the criminal sexual conduct with a minor indictment to assault with intent to commit criminal sexual conduct with a minor, first degree.Â  Sosbee objected to the proposed amendment, and the parties discussed the matter in chambers.Â  The court granted the amendment, and Sosbee noted his objection for the record.Â  Sosbee was convicted of assault with intent to commit criminal sexual conduct with a minor, first degree, and committing a lewd act upon a minor. 
During sentencing, the State informed the court that Sosbee had a 1993 conviction for criminal sexual conduct, second degree, and a â€œDUI record in 1983, and a criminal domestic violence record in 1995.â€Â  Sosbee objected, arguing the prior criminal sexual conduct conviction should not be used to enhance his sentence to life imprisonment without the possibility of parole because it was an uncounseled guilty plea.Â  The court sentenced Sosbee to life imprisonment without the possibility of parole.Â  He appeals.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Sentencing
Sosbee argues the trial court erred in sentencing him to life imprisonment without the possibility of parole because assault with intent to commit criminal sexual conduct with a minor was not a â€œmost seriousâ€ offense that would qualify him for the sentence under the â€œtwo strikesâ€ statute.Â  He also argues that the prior conviction should not have been used for sentence enhancement because it was the result of an uncounseled conviction.Â  We disagree. 
A.   Most Serious Offense
Sosbee initially argues the trial court erred in sentencing him to life without the possibility of parole because, although criminal sexual conduct with minors in any degree is a â€œmost seriousâ€ offense in section 17-25-45(C)(1), assault with intent to commit criminal sexual conduct with a minor, first degree, is not specifically enumerated in the statute.Â  Thus, he argues, it is not a â€œmost seriousâ€ offense.[2]Â  
Sosbeeâ€™s argument lacks merit.Â  Section 17-25-45 clearly designates criminal sexual conduct with a minor as a â€œmost seriousâ€ offense.Â  Section 17-25-45 also designates any â€œattempt, for any offense enumerated in this itemâ€ as a most serious offense.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45(C)(1) (Supp. 2005).Â  An assault with intent to commit criminal sexual conduct with a minor in the first degree is more aptly designated as an â€œattemptâ€ to commit criminal sexual conduct with a minor.Â  See State v. LaCoste, 347 S.C. 153, 165-66, 553 S.E.2d 464, 471 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œAssault is an attempted battery or an â€˜unlawful attempt or offer to commit a violent injury upon another person, coupled with the present ability to complete the attempt or offer by a battery.â€™â€ (emphasis added) (quoting State v. Sutton, 340 S.C. 393, 397, 532 S.E.2d 283, 285 (2000))); see also 6 Am. Jur. 2d Assault & Battery Â§ 1 (1999) (defining assault as the â€œintentional attempt by a person, by force or violence, to do an injury to the person of another, or as any attempt to commit a battery, or any threatening gesture showing in itself or by words accompanying it an immediate intention, coupled with a present ability, to commit a batteryâ€); Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 109; 123 (7th ed. 1999)(defining assault as an â€œattempt to commit battery, requiring the specific intent to cause physical injury;â€ and defining attempt as â€œan overt act that is done with the intent to commit a crime but that falls short of completing the crimeâ€). 
Moreover, in construing these related statutes together, it is clear that the legislature intended this offense to be considered a â€œmost seriousâ€ offense.Â  State v. Gordon, 356 S.C. 143, 152-53, 588 S.E.2d 105, 110 (2003) (â€œIn construing statutory language, the statute must be read as a whole, and sections which are part of the same general statutory law must be construed together and each one given effect . . . if possible we will construe a statute so as to escape an absurd result and carry the legislative intention into effectâ€).Â  Criminal sexual conduct with a minor is defined in South Carolina Code section 16-3-655.[3]Â  Section 16-3-655 specifically designates the prohibited conduct as criminal sexual conduct in the first degree or criminal sexual conduct in the second degree.Â  Both of these are listed as most serious offenses in section 17-25-45.Â  As previously stated, section 17-25-45 also designates any attempt to commit these offenses as most serious.Â  See State v. Morgan, 352 S.C. 359, 367, 574 S.E.2d 203, 207 (Ct. App. 2002) (noting that where the terms of a statute are clear, the court must apply the plain meaning of those terms, and that the statute should receive a â€œpractical, reasonable, and fair interpretation consonant with purpose, design, and policy of lawmakersâ€); see also State v. Brock, 335 S.C. 267, 271, 516 S.E.2d 212, 214 (Ct. App. 1999) (citing sections 16-3-655 and 16-3-656 to define first-degree assault with intent to commit criminal sexual conduct with a minor).Â  Accordingly, we find no error in designating assault with intent to commit criminal sexual conduct with a minor as a â€œmost seriousâ€ offense. 
B.   Uncounseled Plea
Sosbee next argues the trial court erred in sentencing him to life without the possibility of parole because the prior sentence used to enhance his sentence was the result of an uncounseled guilty plea.Â  
The use of an uncounseled conviction resulting in a sentence of imprisonment to enhance the punishment in a subsequent conviction violates the Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution. Â Nichols v. United States, 511 U.S. 738, 746-47 (1994).Â  However, an uncounseled conviction that does not result in actual imprisonment may be used to enhance a subsequent conviction.Â  Id. at 748-49; State v. Wickenhauser, 309 S.C. 377, 380, 423 S.E.2d 344, 346 (1992) (holding that the use of the defendantâ€™s prior, uncounseled DUI conviction was properly used to enhance his punishment in a subsequent offense where the prior sentence was suspended upon the service of probation and he was not incarcerated); State v. Chance, 304 S.C. 406, 407-08, 405 S.E.2d 375, 376 (1991) (noting that the trial court could enhance the defendantâ€™s DUI conviction with a prior uncounseled guilty plea where the defendant was not actually incarcerated).Â  It is the defendantâ€™s burden to prove by a preponderance of the evidence that a prior conviction is constitutionally defective or invalid when objecting to the use of the prior conviction to enhance punishment of a subsequent conviction.Â  State v. Payne, 332 S.C. 266, 269, 504 S.E.2d 335, 336 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  
Sosbee testified at his pre-trial competency hearing that he had a prior conviction for â€œanother sexual thing, but it was with an older woman.â€Â  Sosbee stated he pleaded guilty to it because he did not know what was going on, he did not have a lawyer, and the State offered him three years probation.Â  Sosbee stated he completed his probationary term.Â  At the sentencing hearing in the present case, Sosbeeâ€™s attorney objected to the use of this prior sexual assault conviction because it was the result of an uncounseled plea.Â  The trial court denied the motion.Â  
We find no merit to Sosbeeâ€™s allegations that his prior uncounseled conviction should not have been used for sentence enhancement.Â  Sosbee did not present any evidence that he was actually incarcerated for the prior, uncounseled conviction.Â  The only evidence before the trial court was Sosbeeâ€™s own testimony that he served only a probationary sentence.Â  Because Sosbee failed to meet his burden of proving the use of his prior, uncounseled plea was unconstitutional and because the record indicates that the prior conviction did not result in imprisonment, we find no error with the trial courtâ€™s use of the prior conviction for sentence enhancement.Â  
II.Â  Amendment of the Indictment
Sosbee asserts the trial court only ordered the indictment for criminal sexual conduct with a minor, first degree, to be amended to assault with intent to commit criminal sexual conduct with a minor, first degree, pursuant to sections 16-3-655(1) and 16-3-656.Â  Because Sosbeeâ€™s sentencing sheet erroneously indicated that he was charged with assault with intent to commit criminal sexual conduct, first degree, in violation of section 16-3-656 with a CDR code of 0253, and because the heading inaccurately lists a violation of section 16-3-652 (criminal sexual conduct in the first degree) with a CDR code of 160, Sosbee argues the trial court erred in allowing the amendment of the indictment because it amounted to a â€œbait and switch.â€Â  We disagree.
â€œAmendments to an indictment are permissible if: (1) they do not change the nature of the offense; (2) the charge is a lesser included offense of the crime charged in the indictment; or (3) the defendant waives presentment to the grand jury and pleads guilty.â€Â  State v. Means, 367 S.C. 374, 385-86, 626 S.E.2d 348, 355 (2006); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-100 (2003) (providing that the trial court may amend the indictment if there is a defect in the indictment or a variance in the charged offense and the proof, as long as the amendment does not change the nature of the offense charged).Â Â  
Sosbee asserts the â€œerroneousâ€ listing on his sentencing sheet of the criminal sexual conduct offenses that pertain to adults, instead of the offenses that pertain to minors, changed the nature of the offense charged and was an impermissible amendment.[4]Â  However, it is undisputed that the court ordered the indictment to be amended to assault with intent to commit criminal sexual conduct with a minor, first degree. Â The court charged the jury on the law of assault with intent to commit criminal sexual conduct with a minor, and the jury found Sosbee guilty of assault with intent to commit criminal sexual conduct with a minor.Â  During sentencing, the court specifically indicated Sosbee was being sentenced to life without the possibility of parole for the conviction of assault with intent to commit criminal sexual conduct with a minor, first degree.Â  
Sosbee does not allege that the amendment itself changed the nature of the offense charged.Â  Sosbeeâ€™s only complaint is with the â€œerroneousâ€ listing of charges and CDR codes on the sentencing sheet.Â  We agree with the State that the charges and CDR codes listed on the sentencing sheet were scrivenerâ€™s errors.Â  The sentencing sheet is not part of the indictment and does not affect the nature of the offense charged.
CONCLUSION
Assault with intent to commit criminal sexual conduct with a minor, like any â€œattemptâ€ crime listed in section 17-25-45, is a â€œmost seriousâ€ offense as defined by statute.Â  Sosbeeâ€™s prior uncounseled plea resulted in no jail time, so it was appropriate for the trial court to consider the conviction to enhance his punishment to life without the possibility of parole.Â  Finally, we find the erroneous listing of charges and CDR codes on Sosbeeâ€™s sentencing sheet was a scrivenerâ€™s error.Â  
Accordingly, the convictions and sentences of Sosbee are
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] A person must be sentenced to life imprisonment without the possibility of parole when convicted of a most serious crime and the person has one or more prior convictions for a most serious crime, or when convicted of a serious crime and the person has two or more convictions for a serious crime.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45(A), (B) (2003 & Supp. 2005).Â  Included in the list of â€œmost seriousâ€ offenses is criminal sexual conduct, criminal sexual conduct with minors, and assault with intent to commit criminal sexual conduct, first and second degree.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45(C)(1) (Supp. 2005).Â  
[3] Â§16-3-655 Criminal sexual conduct with minors. 
(A) A person is guilty of criminal sexual conduct in the first degree if: 

  (1) the actor engages in sexual battery with the victim who is less than eleven years of age;Â  or 
  (2) the actor engages in sexual battery with a victim who is less than sixteen years of age and the actor has previously been convicted of, pled guilty or nolo contendere to, or adjudicated delinquent for an offense listed in Section 23‑3‑430(C) or has been ordered to be included in the sex offender registry pursuant to Section 23‑3‑430(D). 

Upon conviction, the actor must be punished by imprisonment for not less than ten years nor more than thirty years, no part of which may be suspended or probation granted. 
(B) A person is guilty of criminal sexual conduct in the second degree if the actor engages in sexual battery with a victim who is fourteen years of age or less but who is at least eleven years of age. 
(C) A person is guilty of criminal sexual conduct in the second degree if the actor engages in sexual battery with a victim who is at least fourteen years of age but who is less than sixteen years of age and the actor is in a position of familial, custodial, or official authority to coerce the victim to submit or is older than the victim. 
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-655 (Supp. 2005) (emphasis added).
[4]Â  Sosbee does not challenge the trial courtâ€™s order amending the indictment from criminal sexual conduct with a minor, first degree, to assault with intent to commit criminal sexual conduct with a minor.Â  Thus, the amendment is the law of the case.Â  State v. Sampson, 317 S.C. 423, 427, 454 S.E.2d 721, 723 (Ct. App. 1995) (holding that an unchallenged ruling, right or wrong, is the law of the case).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        O. Grady Query, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Carmen Burgess and State of South Carolina, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Mikell R. Scarborough, Master-In-Equity

Opinion No. 4178
Submitted October 1, 2006 â€“ Filed November 13, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Kerry W. Koon and Philip A. Middleton, of Charleston, for Appellant.
        Assistant Deputy Attorney General J. Emory Smith, of Columbia; Ben A. Hagood, Jr., of Mt. Pleasant, for Respondents.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â  This is an action to determine title to real property.Â  Appellant O. Grady Query brought a declaratory judgment action against respondents Carmen Burgess and the State of South Carolina seeking to establish ownership over certain marshlands abutting his Folly Beach property.Â  The master found Query did not own the marshlands.Â  The master concluded the State owned the marshlands based on the â€œpublic trust doctrine.â€Â  Query appeals, and we affirm.[1] 
I.
Burgess, a Folly Beach property owner, asked Query, a fellow Folly Beach property owner, for permission to build a dock across certain marshlands abutting Queryâ€™s property so Burgess could access the Folly River.Â  When Query refused, Burgess sought a permit from the Office of Coastal Resource Management to build a dock across the marshlands.Â  In response, Query brought a declaratory judgment action against Burgess and the State[2] seeking to establish title over the marshlands.Â  At trial, Query claimed ownership of the marshlands because the State specifically granted the marshlands to one of his predecessors in title.Â  
Query introduced a 1696 and 1786 grant (with accompanying plat), which he argued showed the Stateâ€™s intent to grant one of his predecessors in title ownership of the marshlands.Â  Burgess and the State asserted Queryâ€™s evidence failed to rebut the presumption the State held the marshlands in fee simple for the benefit of the public.Â  The master agreed with Burgess and the State and found the State held title to the marshlands in fee simple.Â  Query appealed this finding.Â  
II.
â€œA suit for declaratory judgment is neither legal nor equitable, but is determined by the nature of the underlying issue.â€Â  Felts v. Richland County, 303 S.C. 354, 356, 400 S.E.2d 781, 782 (1991).Â  â€œTo make this determination we look to the main purpose of the action as determined by the complaint.â€Â  Estate of Revis v. Revis, 326 S.C. 470, 476, 484 S.E.2d 112, 115 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Where, as here, the main purpose of the complaint concerns the determination of title to real property, it is an action at law.Â  Lowcountry Open Land Trust v. State, 347 S.C. 96, 101, 552 S.E.2d 778, 781 (Ct. App. 2001) (citing Wigfall v. Fobbs, 295 S.C. 59, 60, 367 S.E.2d 156, 157 (1988) (â€œThe determination of title to real property is a legal issue.â€)).Â  In an action at law, â€œwe will affirm the masterâ€™s factual findings if there is any evidence in the record which reasonably supports them.â€Â  Id. at 101-02, 552 S.E.2d at 781.Â  
III.
Query argues the 1786 grant and accompanying plat evince the Stateâ€™s intent to grant Queryâ€™s predecessor in title ownership over the marshlands.Â Â Â  
â€œ[T]he State holds presumptive title to land below the high water mark.â€Â  McQueen v. S.C. Coastal Council, 354 S.C. 142, 149, 580 S.E.2d 116, 119 (2003).Â  When property is bounded by a tidal navigable waterway[3] â€œthe boundary line is the high water mark, in the absence of more specific language showing that it was intended to go below high water mark, and the portion between high and low water mark remains in the State in trust for the benefit of the public.â€Â  State v. Hardee, 259 S.C. 535, 539, 193 S.E.2d 497, 499 (1972).Â  â€œThe State may, however, grant private individuals an ownership interest in tidelands.â€Â  Lowcountry, 347 S.C. at 102, 552 S.E.2d at 781.Â  To establish ownership of tidelands or marshlands, a claimant must show (1) the claimantâ€™s predecessors in title possessed a valid grant, and (2) the grantâ€™s language was sufficient to convey title to land below the high water mark.Â  Id. at 103, 552 S.E.2d at 782.Â  â€œA deed or grant by [the State] is construed strictly in favor of the State and general public and against the grantee.â€Â  Hardee, 259 S.C. at 539, 193 S.E.2d at 499.Â  
The 1786 grant on which Query relies provides:

  We have granted, and by these Presents do grant unto the said Martha Samways, her Heirs and Assigns, a Plantation or Tract of Land containing one thousand nine hundred [and] forty Acres being the Surplus contained in a Grant for the Folly Islands heretofore Granted to William Rivers on the [ninth] of September 1696 for seven hundred acres or thereabouts but upon a Resurvey found to contain within the lines of the same two thousand Six hundred and Forty having such Shape, Form and Marks, as are represented by a Plat hereunto annexed, together with all Woods, Trees, Waters, Water-courses, Profits, Commodities, Appurtenances, and Hereditaments, whatsoever thereunto belonging, To have and to hold the said Tract of one Thousand nine hundred [and] forty Acres of Land, and all and singular other the Premises hereby granted unto the said Martha Samways her Heirs and Assigns for ever . . . .

The accompanying plat includes the following surveyorâ€™s note:

  I have caused to be admeasured [and] resurveyed unto Martha Samways . . . an Island situate in the district of Charleston Granted to Wm. Rivers the [ninth] Sept. 1696 â€“ for the Folly Islands for seven hundred acres or thereabouts, but upon the said resurvey found to contain within the lines of the same two thousand six hundred [and] forty acres â€“ nineteen hundred [and] forty acres thereof being surplus, [and] hath such Form, Marks, Buttings [and] Boundings as the above Plat represents.

The plat roughly delineates Folly Island.Â  The plat contains the bare bones of a survey and is neither precise nor detailed.Â  
The master examined the 1786 grant and accompanying plat and found they lacked the requisite specificity to indicate the Stateâ€™s intent to grant the marshlands to one of Queryâ€™s predecessors in title.Â  The master noted the absence of terms consonant with granting property below the high water mark, such as â€œmarsh,â€ â€œmarshland,â€ â€œhigh-water mark,â€ or â€œlow-water mark.â€Â  Based on these factual findings, the master reasonably determined the 1786 grant and accompanying plat did not demonstrate the Stateâ€™s intent to grant title to the marshlands.Â  The master thus found the plat was not sufficiently detailed to rebut the Stateâ€™s presumption of title to land below the Â high water mark.Â  See Hobonny Club, Inc. v. McEachern, 272 S.C. 392, 398, 252 S.E.2d 133, 136 (1979) (holding that an exceptionally detailed and mathematically precise plat can rebut the Stateâ€™s presumption of title to marshes).Â  Because there is evidence to support the masterâ€™s findings, his order is 
AFFIRMED.[4]
HEARN, C.J., and STILWELL, J., concur. 

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.Â Â Â  
[2]Â  â€œAny person claiming an interest in tidelands . . . may institute an action against [the State] for the purpose of determining the existence of any right, title or interest of such person in and to such tidelands as against the State.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 48-39-220(A) (Supp. 2005).Â  
[3]Â  Query concedes the Folly River is a tidal navigable waterway.Â  
[4]Â  In light of this disposition, we need not address Queryâ€™s remaining issue.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Lea Ann Wilkinson (surviving spouse) for Scott R. Wilkinson (deceased employee),
Respondent,
v.
Palmetto State Transp. Co., Employer, and Canal Insurance Co., Carrier,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Pickens County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4179
Submitted October 1, 2006 â€“ Filed November 20, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
Duke K. McCall, Jr., of Greenville, for Appellants.
KathrynÂ  Williams, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.: Palmetto State Transportation Company and its carrier, Canal Insurance Company (jointly referred to as Palmetto), appeal a circuit court order affirming the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionâ€™s (Commission) award of benefits to Scott Wilkinsonâ€™s dependents.Â  Palmetto argues the trial court erred in affirming the Commissionâ€™s: (1) finding that an employer/employee relationship existed between Palmetto and Scott; (2) denial of a motion to include additional evidence; (3) finding that an occupational disability policy purchased by Scott is a collateral source; (4) denial of a motion to join Zurich American Insurance Company (Zurich), the provider of Scottâ€™s occupational disability policy, as a party defendant; and (5) denying the testimony of Gary Smith, Palmettoâ€™s expert.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
On May 16, 2002, while driving a transfer truck, Scott Wilkinson was involved in a fatal accident in Virginia.Â  Â 
Scottâ€™s spouse, Lea Ann Wilkinson, contends that during the time of the accident, Scott was an employee of Palmetto.Â  As such, she and the coupleâ€™s son are entitled to death benefits from Palmettoâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation carrier under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  Palmetto argues that at the time of his death, Scott was an independent contractor and not an employee; therefore, Lea Ann is not entitled to receive benefits from Palmetto.Â  To support this argument, Palmetto contends in 1998, Scott was hired as an employee, but in May 1999 and again in 2000, the parties signed a contract in which Scott was named as an independent contractor and Palmetto as the carrier. 
Palmetto further avers that even if this Court were to find an employer/employee relationship existed, Palmettoâ€™s liability should be offset by any benefits paid to Lea Ann by the occupational disability policy Scott purchased from Zurich.Â  Lea Ann argues this policy is wholly a collateral source; therefore, Palmetto is not entitled to receive any credit from payments made by Zurich.Â  
On February 27, 2004, the Commissioner found an employer/employee relationship existed between Scott and Palmetto at the time of his death, and Lea Ann and the coupleâ€™s child were entitled to receive death benefits under Palmettoâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation policy.Â  In addition, the Commissioner held that Scottâ€™s occupational disability policy constituted a collateral source.Â  Thus, Palmetto was not entitled to receive credit for benefits paid from that policy, nor could Palmetto receive benefits directly from that policy.Â  
Prior to this ruling, Palmetto filed a motion to add Zurich as an additional party referencing the occupational disability policy purchased by Scott.Â  In addition, Palmetto filed a motion to include additional evidence.Â  The Commissioner denied both motions. 
Consequently, Palmetto appealed to the Full Commission, asserting that the Commissioner erred in denying these motions.Â  On September 28, 2004, the Commissionâ€™s Appellate Panel affirmed and adopted the Commissionerâ€™s order.Â  On September 25, 2005, Palmetto appealed to the circuit court, which affirmed the Commission.Â  Palmetto now appeals to this Court. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The Administrative Procedures Act applies to appeals from decisions of the Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  In an appeal from the Commission, neither this Court nor the circuit court may substitute its judgment for that of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, but it may reverse when the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Corbin v. Kohler Co., 351 S.C. 613, 617, 571 S.E.2d 92, 95 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
â€œAny review of the [C]ommissionâ€™s factual findings is governed by the substantial evidence standard.â€Â  Lockridge v. Santens of Am., Inc., 344 S.C. 511, 515, 544 S.E.2d 842, 844 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Accordingly, we limit review to deciding whether the Commissionâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.Â  Corbin, 351 S.C. at 617, 571 S.E.2d at 95. 
â€œSubstantial evidence is evidence that, in viewing the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the same conclusion that the full commission reached.â€Â  Lockridge, 344 S.C. at 515, 544 S.E.2d at 844.Â  â€œThe â€˜possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s finding from being supported by substantial evidence.â€™â€Â  Lee v. Harborside CafÃ©, 350 S.C. 74, 78, 564 S.E.2d 354, 356 (Ct. App. 2002) (quoting Palmetto Alliance, Inc. v. S.C. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 282 S.C. 430, 432, 319 S.E.2d 695, 696 (1984)).
However, if any factual issue before the Commission involves a jurisdictional question, this Court is not bound by the Commissionâ€™s findings of fact; but it can take its own view of the preponderance of the evidence on that issue.Â  Wilson v. Georgetown County, 316 S.C. 92, 94, 447 S.E.2d 841, 842 (1994).
LAW/ANALYSIS
A. Employer/employee relationship 
Palmetto initially argues the trial court and the Commission erred in concluding that an employer/employee relationship existed between Palmetto and Scott.Â  We disagree. 
Unless an employment relationship existed between the parties at the time of the alleged injury, an award cannot be granted.Â  Alewine v. Tobin Quarries, 206 S.C. 103, 109, 33 S.E.2d 81, 83 (1945).Â  Whether such a relationship exists is a jurisdictional question; therefore, this Court can take its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  S.C. Workersâ€™ Comp. Commâ€™n v. Ray Covington Realtors, Inc., 318 S.C. 546, 547, 459 S.E.2d 302, 303 (1995).Â  However, doubts of jurisdiction are to be resolved in favor of inclusion rather than exclusion.Â  Horton v. Baruch, 217 S.C. 48, 56, 59 S.E.2d 545, 548 (1950).Â Â  
Palmetto places great weight on the agreement the parties signed in May 1999 and again in 2000, in which Scott was named as an independent contractor and Palmetto as the carrier.Â  However, Palmetto forgets neither the descriptions of relationships as set forth in the partiesâ€™ contract, nor the language in the contract declaring the parties to be that of independent contractor/carrier is binding on this Court.Â  Kilgore Group Inc. v. S.C. Employment Sec. Commâ€™n, 313 S.C. 65, 69, 437 S.E.2d 48, 50 (1993).Â  Rather, the determination of whether the worker is an employee or independent contractor is a fact-specific matter resolved by applying certain established principles.Â  Nelson v. Yellow Cab Co., 349 S.C. 589, 594 564 S.E.2d 110, 112-13 (2002).
The test to determine whether a claimant is an employee or an independent contractor is if â€œthe alleged employer has the right and authority to control and direct the particular work or undertaking, as to the manner or means of its accomplishment.â€Â  S.C. Workersâ€™ Comp. Commâ€™n v. Ray Covington Realtors, Inc., 318 S.C. 546, 547, 459 S.E.2d 302, 303 (1995) (internal quotes omitted).Â  Four factors determine the right of control. 
They are: (1) direct evidence of right to or exercise of control, (2) method of payment, (3) furnishing of equipment, and (4) right to fire.Â  Tharpe v. G.E. Moore Co., 254 S.C. 196, 200, 174 S.E.2d 397, 399 (1970).Â  The presence of any one of the factors is sufficient proof of an employer/employee relationship; on the other hand, the absence of any one of the factors is at most mild influential evidence of contractorship.Â  Dawkins v. Jordan, 341 S.C. 434, 439, 534 S.E.2d 700, 703 (2000). 
In analyzing these factors, the Court recognizes that the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act favors the inclusion of employers and employees and not their exclusion.Â  Horton, 217 S.C. at 56, 59 S.E.2d at 548.Â  Â Â With this introduction in mind, we now turn our attention to these four factors. 
The first factor is whether direct evidence exists of the right to, or the actual exercise of, control.Â  If an alleged employer has the right to control and sets out the manner in which the work is to be accomplished, this is direct evidence of an employer/employee relationship.Â  Young v. Warr, 252 S.C. 179, 189-90, 165 S.E.2d 797, 802 (1969).Â  Palmetto contends it lacked control over Scott because Scott could refuse loads and consequently worked on his own schedule.Â  We find this argument to be without merit.Â  
Palmetto exercised its control over Scott by requiring Scott to exclusively carry its loads.Â  When Scott carried a load for Palmetto, he was instructed on when and where to pick up the load as well as how and when to deliver the load.Â  Moreover, Palmetto required Scott to apply the company logo to his truck.Â  This is sufficient evidence to prove that Palmetto not only had the right to control Scott but exercised this control.Â  See Nelson v. Yellow Cab Co., 349 S.C. 589, 597-98, 564 S.E.2d 110, 114 (2002) (Cab company had the right of control even when the cab driver could work as little as he wanted, drove the cab in any part of the city he chose, and could set his own schedule.).
The second factor for consideration is the method of payment; this factor indicates a lack of an employer/employee relationship.Â  Like other employed drivers, Palmetto paid Scott by the mile.Â  However, unlike other employed drivers, Scottâ€™s rate per mile was higher, and Palmetto made no deductions for either social security or income taxes.Â  Moreover, unlike other employed drivers, Scott had to pay various expenses such as fuel costs, service fees, and toll fees.Â  These facts indicate that Scott was not paid like other employed drivers. 
The third factor is whether Palmetto furnished Scottâ€™s equipment; this factor indicates that Scott was an employee.Â  Although Scott purchased his own tractor, Palmetto supplied the trailer.Â  In addition, Palmetto prohibited Scott from using the tractor to carry loads for any other company.Â  Moreover, Scott drove a truck bearing the Palmetto logo. 
Like all of Palmettoâ€™s drivers, Palmetto required Scott to carry a global positioning system (GPS) in his truck.Â  Palmettoâ€™s safety and maintenance director, Dennis Mersereau, testified that by employing this system, Palmetto would be able to determine Scottâ€™s location anytime.Â  These facts show that Palmetto supplied equipment to Scott. 
The final factor is Palmettoâ€™s right to fire, which indicates that Scott was not an independent contractor.Â  The unconditional power to terminate the alleged employer/employee relationship, without liability, is consistent with an employer/employee relationship.Â  Tharpe v. G.E. Moore Co., 254 S.C. 196, 201, 174 S.E.2d 397, 399 (1970).Â  There were many circumstances in which Palmetto could fire Scott. 
For example, Mr. Mersereau testified Scott was required to work exclusively for Palmetto, and if he were to transport loads for another company, he would be terminated.Â  Mr. Mersereau also testified that even though Scott could refuse loads, if he refused too many, Scott would be terminated. Â Palmetto could end the relationship if it did not approve of the manner in which Scott performed his work.Â  Additionally, Scott, like any other employee, could terminate his position with Palmetto at will.Â  
Keeping in mind the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act favors the inclusion of employers and employees and not their exclusion, and the presence of any one of the factors is sufficient proof of an employer/employee relationship, we hold an employer/employee relationship existed between Scott and Palmetto. 
B. Motion to include additional evidence
Palmetto next argues the Commission and the trial court erred by not allowing Palmetto to supplement the record with additional evidence.Â  We disagree. Â 
For additional evidence to be introduced, the moving party must establish that the additional evidence sought to be introduced â€œwas not known to the moving party at the time of the first hearing, [or] by reasonable diligence the new evidence could not have been secured, and the discovery of the new evidence is being brought to attention of the Commission immediately upon its discovery.â€Â  23A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-707 (Supp. 2005).Â  Â Additionally, the admission or exclusion of evidence is within the sound discretion of the Commission. Â Holcombe v. Dan River Mills/Woodside Div., 286 S.C. 223, 225-26, 333 S.E.2d 338, 340 (Ct. App. 1985). 
By motion, Palmetto sought to introduce into the record its own additional business records and an affidavit from Mr. Mersereau.Â  
Although the hearing in this matter occurred during August 2003, the business records were created during or before May 2002.Â  Thus, the records were in existence prior to the hearing and could have been discovered prior to the hearing with due diligence.Â  Likewise, Mr. Mersereauâ€™s affidavit is exclusively based on evidence that existed prior to the hearing and that could have been discovered and submitted prior to the hearing with due diligence. 
Additionally, the records sought to be admitted were subpoenaed by the claimant during June 2002, and Palmetto failed to produce the records claiming that they did not exist.Â  Based on Palmettoâ€™s failure the trial court concluded that allowing the untimely inclusion of the records would prejudice the claimant.Â  We agree. Â 
C. Occupational disability policy 
Palmetto next argues the Commission and the trial court erred in holding Scottâ€™s occupational disability policy was a collateral source. Â We disagree. 
Palmetto argues it should receive credit for any payments made to Lea Ann by the occupational disability policy Scott purchased through Zurich.Â  Lea Ann argues the Zurich policy is a wholly collateral source; therefore, Palmetto should not be able to receive credit for payments made by Zurich. 
The collateral source rule states that compensation from an independent source will not reduce the payment for which another party is liable to the injured party.Â  Atkinson v. Orkin Extermination Co., Inc., 361 S.C. 156, 172, 604 S.E.2d 385, 393 (2004).Â  Unfortunately, an exhaustive search of South Carolina law has failed to yield an answer to whether an occupational disability policy would be considered a collateral source.Â  However, North Carolina courts have addressed this issue.Â  Our courts give great weight to North Carolinaâ€™s decisions in workersâ€™ compensation cases because South Carolina adopted large portions of North Carolinaâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation legislation.Â  Munn v. Nucor Steel, Div. of Nucor Corp., 336 S.C. 28, 31, Â 518 S.E.2d 289, 290 (Ct. App. 1999); See Anderson v. Baptist Med. Ctr. Center, 343 S.C. 487, 496-97, 541 S.E.2d 526, 530 (2001). 
North Carolina courts have ruled that an employer is entitled to receive credit only for any payments made by the employer to the injured employee which were not payable when made. Â Jenkins v. Piedmont Aviation Servs., 557 S.E.2d 104, 108-109 (N.C. App. 2001) (emphasis added).Â  This credit is inapplicable to
all other payments the employee may receive from outside sources. Â Id.
It is undisputed that Scott paid all of the premiums for the Zurich policy, and Palmetto did not contribute in any way to the premiums.Â  Therefore, Palmetto should not receive any credit for payments made by Zurich. 
Additionally, it flies in the face of equity to grant Palmetto a windfall benefit by allowing it to take credit against any sums Lea Ann received from other sources.Â  This is especially true in light of the fact that Scott paid all the premiums, and Palmetto contributed in no way to the Zurich policy. Â 
For these reasons, we hold that Palmetto is not entitled to receive credit for any payments made by Zurich. 
D. Motion to join Zurich
Palmetto next contends the Commission and the trial court erred in not allowing it to add Zurich as a party defendant.Â  Palmetto argues two alternative grounds for this contention.Â  First, the Zurich policy was a workersâ€™ compensation policy, and second, Zurich would reimburse Palmetto for any benefits Palmetto paid.Â  We disagree. 
The Zurich policy states: â€œThis Policy is not intended to provide coverage for Workersâ€™ Compensation benefits.â€Â  As noted above, the Zurich policy was an outside source.Â  As such, Palmetto is not entitled to receive any reimbursement for payments made by Zurich. 
In support of its second contention, Palmetto places great weight on a clause in Zurichâ€™s policy, which would allow Palmetto to receive benefits from Zurich if Palmetto is determined liable for workersâ€™ compensation benefits[1].Â  However, this clause has no binding effect on this Court. 
The parties are free to contract as they wish, but this freedom is not absolute.Â  Statutory provisions that are applicable to a contract become part of that contract.Â  Boyd v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 260 S.C. 316, 319, 195 S.E.2d 706, 707 (1973).Â  If a contract provision contravenes an applicable statute, that provision is invalid, and the statute prevails.Â  Id.  
Under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act, an agreement between an employee and employer for the employee to pay any portion of premiums for benefits required by the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act is invalid.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-5-200 (1976).Â  Additionally, no contract between an employee and employer or an employee and a third party can operate to relieve the obligations created under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act. Â See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-610 (1976). 
As already established, Scott was an employee of Palmetto at the time of his death, and any credit received by Palmetto from the Zurich policy, for which Scott alone paid the premiums would have the effect of replacing the workersâ€™ compensation benefits Palmetto is required to pay under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  Permitting Palmetto to recover these payments would be contrary to South Carolina law, and any provision of the Zurich policy that would allow such payment would violate the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act and therefore would be void. 
The Zurich policy has no bearing on the workersâ€™ compensation claims asserted by Scottâ€™s dependents. Â As such, it is unnecessary to add Zurich as a party defendant because it has no interest in the matter. 
E. Testimony of Gary Smith, Palmettoâ€™s expert
Palmettoâ€™s final argument is that the Commission and the trial court erred in not allowing the testimony of Gary Smith.Â  We disagree.
Palmetto sought to introduce Smithâ€™s testimony to show the construction, purpose, and effect of the Zurich policy.Â  Specifically, through Smith, Palmetto wished to show that if Palmetto is liable for workersâ€™ compensation benefits, the Zurich policy would reimburse Palmetto. 
Smithâ€™s testimony was unnecessary because the Zurich policy has no effect on the workersâ€™ compensation benefits sought, and the policy provides no credit or benefits to Palmetto.Â  Thus, the trial court did not err in excluding Smithâ€™s testimony. 
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.[2]Â 
GOOLSBY and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] The clause states: â€œIf a Covered person is determined by a court of law . . . to be covered under workersâ€™ compensation for a Covered Loss, any benefits for which the Covered person is eligible are payable to the person who was determined to be the Covered Personâ€™s employer. . . .â€Â  
[2] We decide this case without oral arguments pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

description: In this civil action, the Appellant avers that the Circuit Judge erred in ruling that Charles A. Burdetteâ€™s estate is not entitled to a share of the Trust referenced by Item VIII(2)(d) of the Last Will and Testament of Bennie W. Burdette on the ground that Charles A.
