text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Donna L. Holcombe-Burdette, as Personal Representative of the
 Estate of Charles A. Burdette, Appellant,
        v.
        Bank of America, successor by merger to Farmerâ€™s
        Bank of Simpsonville, and Bertha B. Bozeman, as Co-Trustees of Trust, Bernie W. Burdette,
        Helen B. Peters, Bertha B. Bozeman, Individually, Robert McPherson Burdette, Alice Diane
        Kervin, and George Benjamin Peters, Respondents. 
In Re: Last Will and Testament of Bennie W. Burdette
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4180
Heard November 9, 2006 â€“ Filed November 27, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James B. Drennan, III, of Spartanburg, for Appellant.
Bertha Bozeman, of Lexington and Laurel R. S. Blair and R. Oâ€™Neil Rabon, Jr., both of Greenville, for Respondents.
      
    
  

__________
ANDERSON, J.:Â  Donna L. Holcome-Burdette, as the personal representative of the estate of Charles A. Burdette (Personal Representative), appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order affirming the order of the probate court finding the testamentary trust (Trust) contained in the last will and testament (Will) of Bennie W. Burdette (Testator) requires a devisee to be living at the time the trust terminates in order to inherit trust assets.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Testator died in 1965 leaving his Will dated February 8, 1955.Â  Testator was predeceased by his wife, Ella, and survived by his five children: Bennie E. Burdette; Helen B. Peters; Bertha B. Bozeman; Claude M. Burdette; and Zelene B. Adams.Â Â Â  
Under Item VIII of his Will, Testator bequeathed the residue of his estate in trust, naming The Farmerâ€™s Bank of Simpsonville (now Bank of America) and Bertha B. Bozeman as co-trustees.Â  Item VIII(2)(c) directs the trustees, in the event of the death of Testatorâ€™s wife, to apply the entire balance of Testatorâ€™s residuary estate to the benefit of his daughter, Helen B. Peters, for her lifetime.Â  Item VIII(2)(d) provides that upon the death of Peters and when her youngest natural child reaches the age of twenty-one, the trust shall cease and be divided as follows: 

One share to the natural child or children per stirpes of my daughter, Helen B. Peters; one share to each of my children, Claude M. Burdette, Zelene B. Adams and Bertha B. Bozeman, living at the time of the termination of said trust.Â  If either of my said three children shall have died before the termination of this trust, leaving a child or children surviving, the child or children of said deceased child of mine shall take per stirpes the share of the corpus and accumulated net income of which his, her or their parent would have taken if living.Â  If any of my four children Helen B. Peters, Claude M. Burdette, Zelene B. Adams and Bertha B. Bozeman, should die without leaving a surviving child or children, the share of the corpus and accumulated net income which the child or children of Helen B. Peters, and the share which my other child or children would have taken if living, Â shall be divided among my surviving children, Claude M. Burdette, Zelene B. Adams, and Bertha B. Bozeman, and the child or children per stirpes of any of my said three deceased children who shall have died leaving a surviving child or children, as the case may be. 

Peters died on July 3, 2003 and was survived by one son who was over the age of twenty-one.Â  Claude M. Burdette died in 1970, predeceasing Peters, but was survived by two sons, one of whom was Charles A. Burdette.Â  Charles A. Burdette also predeceased Peters and was not living at the time the trust terminated.Â Â Â Â  
In December 2003, Personal Representative filed this action requesting the probate court to find, pursuant to Item VIII (2)(d), Charles A. Burdette had a vested remainder interest in the Trust based on having survived his father, Claude M. Burdette.Â  The probate court held the plain language of Testatorâ€™s Will â€œclearly articulates the Settlorâ€™s intention that the assets pass lineally, per stirpes, to heirs surviving Helen B. Peters and living at the time of Trust termination, or to their surviving children.â€Â  On appeal, the circuit court affirmed the ruling of the probate court. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An appellate courtâ€™s determination of the standard of review for matters originating in the probate court is controlled by whether the cause of action is at law or in equity.Â  Golini v. Bolton, 326 S.C. 333, 338, 482 S.E.2d 784, 787 (Ct. App. 1997); Univ. of S. Cal. v. Moran, 365 S.C. 270, 274, 617 S.E.2d 135, 137 (Ct. App. 2005).
The construction of a will is an action at law.Â  Epworth Childrenâ€™s Home v. Beasley, 365 S.C. 157, 165, 616 S.E.2d 710, 714 (2005); Estate of Stevens v. Lutch, 365 S.C. 427, 430, 617 S.E.2d 736, 737 (Ct. App. 2005); Nationsbank of S.C. v. Greenwood, 321 S.C. 386, 392, 468 S.E.2d 658, 662 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  â€œOn appeal from an action at law that was tried without a jury, the appellate court can correct errors of law, but the findings of fact will not be disturbed unless found to be without evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.â€Â  Blackmon v. Weaver, 366 S.C. 245, 249, 621 S.E.2d 42, 44 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Because Personal Representative has admitted that no facts are in dispute in this case, this court can review conclusions of law based on those facts.Â  See Coakley v. Horace Mann Ins. Co., 363 S.C. 147, 152, 609 S.E.2d 537, 540 (Ct. App. 2005).Â Â  Â 
In the case sub judice, a trust is encapsulated within the four corners of a will.Â  An action to construe or interpret a testamentary trust is equitable in nature.Â  Waddell v. Kahdy, 309 S.C. 1, 4-5, 419 S.E.2d 783, 785-86 (1992).Â  A declaration of rights arising in the administration of a trust generally lies in equity.Â  See First Citizens Bank and Trust Co. of S.C. v. Hucks, 305 S.C. 296, 298, 408 S.E.2d 222, 223 (1991).
It is not necessary for this Court to resolve the obvious conundrum as to whether the standard of review in this case is at law or in equity.Â  Applying either standard, the result will be the same. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Personal Representative argues the trial court erred in finding any interest Charles A. Burdette had in the residuary of Testatorâ€™s estate (to be distributed at the dissolution of the trust) was conditioned upon Charles A. Burdette surviving Helen B. Peters.Â  Specifically, Personal Representative avers Charles A. Burdetteâ€™s interest in the Trust assets vested at the time Claude M. Burdette died in 1970 because no condition precedent remainedâ€”the only condition precedent was that Charles survive his father, Claude.Â  It is Personal Representativeâ€™s contention that, while Testator intended to require that his three named children survive their sister Helen in order to take a share of the Trust principal at her death, he did not desire this same requirement be placed on their children, i.e. his grandchildren.Â  We disagree.Â  
1. Construction of Wills
The paramount rule of will construction is to determine and give effect to the testatorâ€™s intent. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-102(b)(2) (â€œThe underlying purposes and policies of this Code are . . . (2) to discover and make effective the intent of a decedent in the distribution of his property.â€); Epworth Childrenâ€™s Home v. Beasley, 365 S.C. 157, 165, 616 S.E.2d 710, 714 (2005); Bob Jones Univ. v. Strandell, 344 S.C. 224, 230, 543 S.E.2d 251, 254 (Ct. App. 2001); Matter of Clark, 308 S.C. 328, 330, 417 S.E.2d 856, 857 (1992) (stating the cardinal rule of will construction, as well as the primary inquiry of the appellate court, is the determination of the testatorâ€™s intent).Â  â€œ[A] testatorâ€™s intention, as expressed in his will, governs the construction of it if not in conflict with law or public policy . . . .â€ Â In re Estate of Prioleau, 361 S.C. 627, 631, 606 S.E.2d 769, 772 (2004); White v. White, 241 S.C. 181, 185, 127 S.E.2d 627, 629 (1962).Â  In construing the provisions of a will, every effort must be made to determine and carry out the intentions of the testator.Â  Prioleau, 361 S.C. at 631, 606 S.E.2d at 772; Citizens & S. Natâ€™l Bank v. Cleveland, 200 S.C. 373, 377, 20 S.E.2d 811, 812 (1942).Â  Indeed, â€œ[t]he rules of construction are subservient to the primary consideration of ascertaining what the testator meant by the terms used in the written instrument itself . . . .â€Â  Kemp v. Rawlings, 358 S.C. 28, 34, 594 S.E.2d 845, 849 (2004); Allison v. Wilson, 306 S.C. 274, 278, 411 S.E.2d 433, 435 (1991); see also Black v. Gettys, 238 S.C. 167, 173, 119 S.E.2d 660, 662-63 (1961) (stating while there are certain rules of construction to be followed in seeking the intention of the testator, they are all subservient to the paramount consideration of determining what the testator meant by the terms used).Â  
In determining the intent of the deceased, a court must always look first to the language of the will itself.Â  Pate v. Ford, 297 S.C. 294, 299, 376 S.E.2d 775, 778 (1989); Bob Jones Univ., 344 S.C. at 230, 543 S.E.2d at 254 (â€œIn construing a will, a courtâ€™s first reference is always to the willâ€™s language itself.â€).Â  The primary rule of ascertaining intent is that â€œ[r]esort is first to be had to the instrumentâ€™s language, and if such is perfectly plain and capable of legal construction, such language determines the force and effect of the instrument.â€Â  Chiles v. Chiles, 270 S.C. 379, 383-84, 242 S.E.2d 426, 429 (1978) (quoting Superior Auto Ins. Co. v. Maners, 261 S.C. 257, 263, 199 S.E.2d 719, 722 (1973)).Â  The court must be guided by the words which the testator has used, reading them in the light of established principles of law.Â  White, 241 S.C. at 186, 127 S.E.2d at 629.Â  
â€œIn construing the language of a will, the appellate court must give words their ordinary, plain meaning unless it is clear the testator intended a different sense, or unless such a meaning would lead to an inconsistency with the testatorâ€™s declared intention.â€ Â Epworth Childrenâ€™s Home, 365 S.C. at 165, 616 S.E.2d at 714-15; accord Bob Jones Univ., 344 S.C. at 230, 543 S.E.2d at 254.Â  â€œA will must be read in the ordinary and grammatical sense of the words employed, unless some obvious absurdity, repugnancy or inconsistency with the declared intention of the testator, as abstracted from the whole will, should follow from such construction.â€Â  Matter of Clark, 308 S.C. at 330, 417 S.E.2d at 857; accord Epworth Childrenâ€™s Home, 365 S.C. at 165, 616 S.E.2d at 715; Love v. Love, 208 S.C. 363, 369, 38 S.E.2d 231, 233 (1946).Â  Only when a willâ€™s terms or provisions are equivocal, may the court resort to extrinsic evidence to resolve the ambiguity.Â  In re Estate of Hyman, 362 S.C. 20, 26, 606 S.E.2d 205, 207 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
In assigning meaning to the words used in the will and ascertaining the intent of the testator, the court must view the will as a whole.Â  See Pate, 297 S.C. at 299, 376 S.E.2d at 778.Â  Intent is to be ascertained upon consideration of the entire will.Â  Epworth Childrenâ€™s Home, 365 S.C. at 165, 616 S.E.2d at 714;Â  Prioleau, 361 S.C. at 631, 606 S.E.2d at 772.Â  â€œ[E]ach item of a will must be considered in relation to the other portion.â€Â  Epworth Childrenâ€™s Home, 365 S.C. at 166, 616 S.E.2d at 715; Allison, 306 S.C. at 278, 411 S.E.2d at 435. Â â€œA court may not consider the will piecemeal, but must give due weight to all its language and provisions, giving effect to every part when, under a reasonable interpretation, all the provisions may be harmonized with each other and with the will as a whole.â€ Â Epworth Childrenâ€™s Home, 365 S.C. at 166, 616 S.E.2d at 715 (citations omitted).Â  Arriving at the intent of the testator requires that every item be considered in relation to the other portions of the will.Â  Gettys, 238 S.C. at 174, 119 S.E.2d at 663.Â  â€œAn interpretation that fits into the whole scheme or plan of the will is most likely to be the correct interpretation of the intent of the testator.â€Â  Epworth Childrenâ€™s Home, 365 S.C. at 166, 616 S.E.2d at 715; accord Lemmon v. Wilson, 204 S.C. 50, 69, 28 S.E.2d 792, 800 (1944).
2. Construction of Trusts
â€œThe rules of construction that apply in this State to the interpretation of and disposition of property by will also apply as appropriate to the interpretation of the terms of a trust and the disposition of the trust property.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann Â§ 62-7-112 (2005 Act No. 66, Â§ 1, effective January 1, 2006). 
The primary consideration in interpreting and construing a testamentary trust is to discern the testatorâ€™s intent. Â Epworth Childrenâ€™s Home, 365 S.C. at 166, 616 S.E.2d at 715; Bowles v. Bradley, 319 S.C. 377, 380, 461 S.E.2d 811, 813 (1995) (â€œThe primary consideration in construing a trust is to discern the settlorâ€™s intent.â€). Â Indeed, â€œthe law relating to discerning the drafterâ€™s intent is identical for wills and trusts.â€Â  Epworth Childrenâ€™s Home, 365 S.C. at 166, 616 S.E.2d at 715 (citing All Saints Parish, Waccamaw v. Protestant Episcopal Church, 358 S.C. 209, 224 n. 10, 595 S.E.2d 253, 262 n. 10 (Ct. App. 2004)). In ascertaining a settlorâ€™s intent, if the language of the trust instrument is perfectly plain and capable of legal construction, such language determines the force and the effect of the instrument. Chiles v. Chiles, 270 S.C. 379, 384, 242 S.E.2d 426, 429 (1978); see also Floyd v. Floyd, 365 S.C. 56, 615 S.E.2d 465 (Ct. App. 2005) (affirming trial courtâ€™s construction of testamentary trust language relating to trusteeâ€™s discretionary powers); Moran, 365 S.C. 270, 617 S.E.2d 135 (construing the plain language of trust specifically to authorize trustee to enter into settlements); Estate of Stevens v. Lutch, 365 S.C. 427, 617 S.E.2d 736 (Ct. App. 2005) (relying on the trust language as most persuasive of settlorâ€™s intent regarding discretionary power of trustee). 
â€œ[C]onstruction depends upon the trustorâ€™s intent at the time of execution as shown by the face of the document and not on any secret wishes, desires or thoughts after the event.â€Â  Chiles, 270 S.C. at 384, 242 S.E.2d at 429 (quoting Brock v. Hall, 33 Cal.2d 885, 206 P.2d 360 (1949)). Extrinsic evidence is not admissible to alter the plain language of a trust instrument.Â  Bowles, 319 S.C. at 380, 461 S.E.2d at 813.
3. VestingÂ  
The word â€œvestâ€ can be employed to refer to either â€œa vesting in interestâ€ or â€œa vesting in possession.â€Â  Loadholt v. Harter, 260 S.C. 176, 181, 194 S.E.2d 880, 883 (1973).Â  As the latter meaning would have no further effect than if the grantor had declared the property was â€œto and be possessed byâ€ the remaindermen upon the death of Helen (and when her youngest child reaches twenty-one years of age), the former use of the term, in the sense of â€œto vest in interest,â€ is unequivocally the meaning of term in the case sub judice.Â  See id. 
Our supreme court has stated:

A vested remainder is one the owner of which has the present capacity of taking the seisin in case the particular estate were to determine. But no degree of uncertainty as to the remaindermanâ€™s ever enjoying his remainder will render it contingent, provided he has by the limitation a present absolute right to enjoy the estate the instant the prior estate should determine.
While a contingent remainder is one limited to take effect either to a dubious and uncertain person or upon a dubious and uncertain event, it does not follow that every remainder which is subject to a contingency or a condition is therefore a contingent remainder. The condition may be precedent or it may be subsequent if the former, the remainder is contingent; if the latter, it is vested, though it may be divested by the happening of the condition.

Peoples Nat. Bank of Greenville v. Hable, 243 S.C. 502, 510, 134 S.E.2d 763, 766 (1964) (internal quotations omitted).
It is not the uncertainty of enjoyment in the future, but the uncertainty of the right to that enjoyment which marks the difference between a vested and a contingent interest.Â  Loadholt, 260 S.C. at 182, 194 S.E.2d at 883 (quoting Walker v. Alverson, 87 S.C. 55, 59, 68 S.E.2d 966, 969 (1910)).
4. ApplicationÂ  
The plain language of the Trust articulates Testatorâ€™s clear intention to pass the Trust assets to heirs living at the time the Trust terminates.Â  It is true, as Personal Representative contends, that the law favors the vesting of estates at the earliest time possible.Â  Gettys, 238 S.C. at 177, 119 S.E.2d at 664-65; Walker, 87 S.C. at 57-58, 68 S.E. at 967.Â  The Trust provides that in the event any of Testatorâ€™s â€œthree children shall have died before the termination of this trust, leaving a child or children surviving, the child or children of said deceased child of mine shall take per stirpes the share of the corpus and accumulated net income of which his, her or their parent would have taken if living.â€ (emphasis added).Â  This language indicates Testator only desired a grandchild to take if he or she were â€œsurvivingâ€ at the time of the termination of the trust. Therefore, the trial court did not err in holding Charles A. Burdetteâ€™s interest in the Trust assets was conditioned upon his surviving Peters.Â  
While a remainder may vest in title before the life estate ends (i.e. â€œdeterminesâ€) at the death of the life tenant, any interest the grandchildren had in the trust property did not vest until the time of Helenâ€™s death.Â  The Trust specifically stated: â€œUpon the death of my daughter, Helen B. Peters [or if later, upon her youngest child reaching the age of twenty-one], the trust herein created in . . . shall cease and determine . . .â€ (emphasis added). Â It was at this point in time, when the trust terminated, that Testator intended vesting to occur.
Our interpretation is further substantiated by consideration of the entire Will and Trust.Â  Throughout these documents, Testator evidences a common scheme of devising assets only to persons surviving him or surviving prior devisees.Â  Testator bequeathed his home to his wife, â€œ[i]f she shall survive me,â€ gave his daughter, Zelene B. Adams, $3,500 for running his business â€œif she shall survive me,â€ and left a vacant lot to his son, Bennie E. Burdette, for life â€œif he shall survive me . . . .â€Â  Upon Bennie E. Burdetteâ€™s death, the vacant lot was directed to pass to Bennie E. Burdetteâ€™s wife, for life, â€œif she be then living.â€Â  Similarly, Testator left Peters a house, for her natural life, â€œif she shall survive meâ€ and instructed that the house shall pass to Petersâ€™ son if he survives until the age of twenty-five and is living at the time of Petersâ€™ death.Â  These other devises indicate Testatorâ€™s general intent to leave assets to heirs living at the time a bequest passes.Â  Thus, in viewing the passage at issue in light of the Will and Trust as a whole, the clear intent of the Testator under Item VIII(2)(d) is to require a devisee be alive at the time of the termination of the Trust in order to take an interest in the Trust assets.
We acknowledge the Testatorâ€™s direct requirement of survivorship in other portions of the Will and Trust could arguably provide support for finding that Testator knew how to specifically require survivorship, and the failure to do so under Item VIII, indicates survivorship is not obligatory.Â  See Thomson v. Russell, 131 S.C. 529, 538-39, 128 S.E. 421, 422 (1924) (holding creation of life estate in one part of will demonstrates knowledge of requirements and that intention in other part is to not create life estate).Â  We read the Trust as clearly requiring survivorship.Â  Further, the circumstances in this case do not lead to interpreting the Trust as the court did in Thompson.Â  We note that â€œwhile precedent is helpful at times,
â€˜no will has a brother,â€™â€ and â€œ[a] court may find little guidance in prior decisions interpreting wills . . . due to the different intent and circumstances of each testator . . . .â€Â  Epworth Childrenâ€™s Home, 365 S.C. at 166, 616 S.E.2d at 715 (citation omitted).Â  Â Â 
CONCLUSION
We rule the language of the Will and Trust clearly indicates Testatorâ€™s intent that the Trust assets pass only to devisees surviving at the time the Trust terminates.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.Â Â Â Â  
HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Danny K. Wright, Respondent,
v.
Ralph C. Craft d/b/a Craft Auto Mart, Inc., Appellant,
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Allison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4181
Heard November 9, 2006 â€“ Filed November 27, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Timothy G. Quinn, of Columbia, for Appellant.
C. Steven Moskos of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.: Danny K. Wright initiated an action against Ralph C. Craft, d/b/a/ Craft Auto Mart, Inc., for revocation of acceptance, breach of contract, negligence, constructive fraud, fraud, violation of the Unfair Trade Practices Act, Â§Â§ 39-5-10 to -560 (UTPA), violation of the Regulation of Manufacturers, Distributors, and Dealers Act, Â§Â§ 56-15-10 to -600 (Dealers Act), and violation of the Federal Odometer Statute.Â  The trial court granted Craft summary judgment on Wrightâ€™s causes of action for fraud and violation of the Federal Odometer Statute.Â  Wright withdrew his causes of action for revocation of acceptance, breach of contract and constructive fraud. The jury rendered verdicts as follows:

(1)Â  Negligenceâ€”The jury awarded Wright actual damages of $25,578 and punitive damages of $12,789. 
(2)Â  UTPAâ€”The jury awarded Wright actual damages of $25,578.
(3) Dealers Actâ€”The jury awarded Wright actual damages of $51,156 and punitive damages of $12,789. 

On Wrightâ€™s motion to treble damages under the UTPA, the trial court required Wright to elect his remedy.Â  Wright chose to proceed under the UTPA.Â  The trial court trebled the UTPA damages and awarded Wright attorneyâ€™s fees in the amount of $70,650 and costs in the amount of $4656.59.Â  Craft filed a motion for a judgment non obstante veredicto (JNOV) and a motion to strike damages, which were denied by the trial court. Â 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Wright purchased a used 2001 Ford F-150 (Truck) from Craft Auto Mart, Inc. (Craft Auto) in July of 2002.Â  When purchased by its first owner the Truck came with a 36,000 mile bumper-to-bumper warranty, which was transferable to subsequent owners.Â  In November of 2001, the Truck was involved in an accident in which it rolled and flipped over.Â  The incident damaged the right quarter panel and the hood of the Truck, broke windows, and caused both air bags to deploy.Â  State Farm Insurance Company bought the Truck from the first owner.
Craft purchased the Truck at a vehicle auction to repair and sell at Craft Auto.Â  The purchase was arranged by an acquaintance, Jim Spoon, whom Craft instructed to buy the Truck if â€œjust the sheet metal was damaged.â€[1]
Craft had the Truck repaired at Bestway Body Shop.Â  Replacements for some of the damaged parts were obtained from the Ford Dealership and others came from Keystone Automotive Industries.Â  Lindsay Brothers supplied a used airbag.[2]Â  Craft saw the Truck about a week after the repair work had begun.Â  He observed some of the wrecked parts and noted that the original airbags had deployed during the wreck. Craft claimed his observations supported his belief that the Truck only had sheet metal damage. 
Craft advertised the Truck for sale as a â€œone-owner vehicleâ€ and did not reveal that the Truck had been wrecked and repaired.Â  Wright saw the advertisement, contacted Craft Auto, and questioned Zack Rickard, an employee, about the Truckâ€™s mileage, warranty, and condition. Â Rickard informed Wright the Truck had ten thousand miles, came with a warranty, and had nothing wrong with it.Â  Wright specifically asked Rickard if the Truck had any damage and Rickard responded that it did not.Â Â Â  
Wright, accompanied by Rickard, test drove the Truck and noticed the check engine and seat belt lights came on.Â  Rickard assured Wright â€œthere would be no problemâ€ because it was covered and would be checked.Â  In addition, Wright observed some exterior damage near the driverâ€™s side door of the Truck and was advised â€œit was done in the parking lot like somebody opened the door and hit it, or it got hit with a grocery cart.â€Â  Wright said he would buy the Truck if â€œeverything that I see wrong with it when Iâ€™m looking at it, heâ€™d have it fixed before I bought it.â€Â  
In attending to the warning lights, Craft took the Truck to Bob Bennett Ford, where he learned that any Truck parts damaged in the wreck or painted because of the wreck would not be covered by the warranty.Â  Moreover, Craft was warned the warranty did not cover parts and components not replaced by genuine Ford parts.Â  Components not covered by warranty included the used airbags from Lindsay and the generic parts from Keystone.
Craft never told Wright the Truck had been wrecked, purchased from State Farm at auction, and repaired.Â  He maintained he did not know what was covered by the factory warranty, nor did he inform Wright about parts he specifically knew were not under factory warranty. 
The Buyerâ€™s Guide Wright received at the time of purchase stated the Truck was sold â€œas is-no warranty.â€Â  Wright inquired about the extent of the warranty and Craft wrote on the back of the Buyerâ€™s Guide â€œfactory warranty, if applicable.â€Â  When Wright asked why the factory warranty was qualified with â€œif applicable,â€ Craft claimed he did not know how much time was remaining on the factory warranty.Â  Craft made an additional notation on the back of the Buyerâ€™s Guide indicating the Truck had â€œprevious paintwork.â€ 
While driving the Truck in September of 2002, Wright observed an illuminated check engine light, which was repaired under warranty at a Ford dealership.Â  A month or so later, Wright experienced the Truck shaking and shutting off.Â  He returned the Truck to the Ford dealership in October of 2002.Â  David McCauley, a mechanic from the Ford dealership who owned the same model F-150, lifted the hood on his own truck to show Wright what the interior under the hood should look like.Â  McCauley explained that if wreck damage was causing the Truckâ€™s trouble, the repair would not be covered under warranty. After learning the Truck had been wrecked, Wright called to complain to Craft, who told Wright there was nothing he could do.Â  Wright grew concerned that the Truck was not safe to drive.Â  
At trial, Ford Motors field service engineer, Stuart Sonnen, testified that repairs are not covered under a factory warranty if the parts used in the repairs are not manufactured by Ford or if the parts are not installed by an authorized Ford agent.Â  Ray Morris, a former car salesman, averred that the Truck had serious safety concerns.Â  Moreover, he claimed that in the retail market, the Truck was valueless in its current condition.Â  John Disher, a Ford-certified body shop owner who qualified as an expert in the field of automotive repair, maintained the welds formed to repair the Truck were not satisfactory and did not meet factory specifications.Â  Disher expressed concern about what might happen to the Truck in another accident.Â  â€œThe structural integrity [of the Truck] ha[d] not been restored and it would probably collapse.â€ Â Â 
Wright claimed his losses as a result of purchasing the Truck from Craft included: (1) $33.18 to have the hood fixed; (2) sixteen Truck payments totaling $6395.04; (3) twelve Truck payments after refinancing totaling $3739.80; (4) $12,766.21 remaining on his Truck loan obligation; and (5) negative equity on the vehicle he traded in for the Truck in the amount of $2643.92. Â Wrightâ€™s total damages amounted to $25,578.15. 
In Craftâ€™s statement of issues on appeal he contends the trial court erred in failing to: (1) grant the motion for directed verdict; (2) grant the motion for JNOV; (3) strike damages from the UTPA cause of action; (4) allow the entry of the Truck into evidence; (5) admit Wrightâ€™s loan application into evidence; and (6) grant the motion for summary judgment. Additionally, Craft appeals the juryâ€™s verdict on the ground it was the result of undue passion and prejudice. Â Apart from his statement of issues on appeal, in his brief Craft asserts that Wright should have been estopped from alleging he suffered damages under the UTPA. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When legal and equitable actions are maintained in one suit, the court is presented with a divided scope of review, and each action retains its own identity as legal or equitable for purposes of review on appeal.Â  Blackmon v. Weaver, 366 S.C. 245, 248-49, 621 S.E.2d 42, 44 (Ct. App. 2005); Kiriakides v. Atlas Food Sys. & Servs., Inc., 338 S.C. 572, 580, 527 S.E.2d 371, 375 (Ct. App. 2000) (citations omitted).Â  The proper analysis is to view the actions separately for the purpose of determining the appropriate standard of review.Â  Jordan v. Holt, 362 S.C. 201, 205, 608 S.E.2d 129, 131 (2005).
Actions at Law
In an action at law, on appeal of a case tried by a jury, the jurisdiction of the appellate court extends merely to the correction of errors of law, and a factual finding by the jury will not be disturbed unless a review of the record discloses there is no evidence which reasonably supports the juryâ€™s findings.Â  Erickson v. Jones Street Publishers, L.L.C., 368 S.C. 444, 464, 629 S.E.2d 663-64 (2006); R & G. Const. Inc., v. Lowcountry Regâ€™l Transp. Auth., 343 S.C. 424, 431, 540 S.E.2d 113, 117 (Ct. App. 2000) cert. dismissed (July 22, 2002) rehearing denied (Aug 21, 2002). Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 85, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  
When reviewing a motion for directed verdict or JNOV, an appellate court must employ the same standard as the trial court.Â  Law v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 368 S.C. 424, 434, 629 S.E.2d 642, 648 (2006); Proctor v. Depâ€™t of Health and Envtl. Control, 368 S.C. 279, 292, 628 S.E.2d 496, 503 (Ct. App. 2006) (citing Elam v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 27-28, 602 S.E.2d 772, 782 (2004)); The Huffines Co., L.L.C. v. Lockhart, 365 S.C. 178, 187, 617 S.E.2d 125, 129 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  On appeal from an order denying a directed verdict, an appellate court views the evidence and all reasonable inferences in a light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Swinton Creek Nursery v. Edisto Farm Credit, 334 S.C. 469, 476, 514 S.E.2d 126, 130 (1999); Mullinax v. Brown Amusement, 326 S.C. 453, 456, 485 S.E.2d 103, 105 (Ct. App. 1997) affâ€™d 333 S.C. 89, 508 S.E.2d 848 (1998).Â  â€œThe appellate court must determine whether a verdict for the opposing party would be reasonably possible under the facts as liberally construed in his favor.â€ Jones v. General Electric Co., 331 S.C. 351, 356, 503 S.E.2d 173, 176 (Ct. App. 1998).Â Â Â  
This court will reverse the trial courtâ€™s ruling on a directed verdict motion only if no evidence exists to support the ruling, or if the decision was controlled by an error of law.Â  Pye v. Estate of Fox, 369 S.C. 555, ___, 633 S.E.2d 505, 509 (2006); McMillan, 367 S.C. at 564, 626 S.E.2d at 886; Clark v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Pub. Safety, 362 S.C. 377, 382-83, 608 S.E.2d 573, 576 (2005); Swinton Creek Nursery, 334 S.C. at 477, 514 S.E.2d at 130; Welch v. Epstein, 342 S.C. 279, 300, 536 S.E.2d 408, 418 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  When considering directed verdict motions, neither the trial court nor the appellate court has authority to decide credibility issues or to resolve conflicts in the testimony or evidence.Â  Erickson, 368 S.C. at 463, 629 S.E.2d at 663.
Actions at Equity
In an action at equity, a reviewing court can find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Key Corporate Capital, Inc. v. County of Beaufort, 360 S.C. 513, 516, 602 S.E.2d 104, 106 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Estoppel is an equitable concept.Â  Cothran v. Brown, 357 S.C. 210, 215, 592 S.E.2d 629, 631 (2004); West v. Newberry Elec. Co-op., 357 S.C. 537, 541, 593 S.E.2d 500, 542 (Ct. App. 2004); Quinn v. Sharon Corp., 343 S.C. 411, 416, 540 S.E.2d 474, 476 (Ct. App. 2000) (Anderson, J., concurring in result only).Â  However, a distinction should be made between cases in which the defendantâ€™s answer asserts merely an equitable defense, and cases in which the answer seeks affirmative equitable relief. Rogers v. Nation, 284 S.C. 330, 332-33, 326 S.C.2d 182, 183 (Ct. App 1985).Â  In the case of an equitable defense, the nature of the action remains the same. Id.; but seeÂ  Brown v. Chandler, 50 S.C. 385, 27 S.E. 868 (1897) (holding an equitable defense in a legal action receives equity review).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Initially, we address several procedural matters, noting that a number of Craftâ€™s issues on appeal are not preserved for our review.Â  When a defendant moves for a directed verdict under Rule 50, SCRCP at the close of the plaintiffâ€™s case, he must renew that motion at the close of all evidence. Hendrix v. E. Distribution, Inc., 316 S.C. 34, 37 446 S.E.2d 440, 442 (Ct. App. 1994) affâ€™d in result, 320 S.C. 218, 464 S.E.2d 112 (1995).Â  See State v. Bailey, 368 S.C. 39, 43, 626 S.E.2d 898, 900 (Ct. App. 2006) (â€œIf a defendant presents evidence after the denial of his motion for a directed verdict at the close of the [plaintiffâ€™s] case, he must make another motion for a directed verdict at the close of all evidence in order to appeal the sufficiency of the evidence.â€); State v. Rosemond, 348 S.C. 621, 560 S.E.2d 636 (Ct. App. 2002), affâ€™d as modified 356 S.C. 426, 589 S.E.2d 757 (2003). Otherwise, this court is precluded from reviewing the denial of the motion on appeal. Hendrix, 316 S.C. at 37, 446 S.E.2d at 442. Craft moved for a directed verdict at the close of Wrightâ€™s case, but failed to renew the motion after concluding his presentation of evidence.Â  Consequently, the denial of Craftâ€™s motion is not preserved for our review.
Concomitantly, a motion for JNOV under Rule 50(b), SCRCP is a renewal of a directed verdict motion.Â  Glover v. N.C. Mut. Life Ins. Co., 295 S.C. 251, 256, 368 S.E.2d 68, 72 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  When a party fails to renew a motion for a directed verdict at the close of all evidence, he waives his right to move for
JNOV.  Henderson v. St. Francis Cmty. Hosp., 295 S.C. 441, 446, 369 S.E.2d 652, 656 (Ct. App. 1988). Â Because Craft did not renew his motion for a directed verdict at the close of all evidence, there is no JNOV motion to review.Â  In addition, Craft identified the denial of the JNOV motion in his statement of issues on appeal but failed to address it in his brief.Â  â€œAn issue raised on appeal but not argued in the brief is deemed abandoned and will not be considered by the appellate court.â€Â 
Fields v. Melrose Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 312 S.C. 102, 106, 439 S.E.2d 283, 284 (Ct. App. 1993); Bell v. Bennett, 307 S.C. 286, 294, 414 S.E.2d 786, 791 (Ct. App. 1992).
The record indicates Craft did not comply with the time requirements under Rule 59, SCRCP in filing his motion to strike damages. Â Moreover, the denial of the motion to strike damages is listed in his statement of issues on appeal, but Craft did not address the denial in his brief.Â  The issue is, therefore, deemed abandoned.Â  Id.Â  Likewise, Craftâ€™s argument that the juryâ€™s verdict was the result of undue passion and prejudice was included in his statement of issues on appeal.Â  Craft failed to pursue the issue in his brief and it is not properly before this court.Â  Id.  
In his brief Craft advanced an argument grounded on a general estoppel theory.Â  However, Craft failed to plead estoppel as a defense in his answer to Wrightâ€™s complaint. â€œEvery defense, in law or fact, to a cause of action in any pleading, whether a claim, counterclaim, cross-claim, or third-party claim, shall be asserted in the responsive pleading thereto . . . .â€Â  Rule 12, SCRCP.Â  â€œ[E]stoppel must be affirmatively [pleaded] as a defense and cannot be bootstrapped onto another claim.â€Â  Collins Entmâ€™t, Inc. v. White, 363 S.C. 546, 562, 611 S.E.2d 262, 270 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing Rule 8, SCRCP); Provident Life & Accident Ins. Co. v. Driver, 317 S.C. 471, 478, 451 S.E.2d 924, 929 (Ct. App. 1994)).Â  The failure to plead an affirmative defense is deemed a waiver of the right to assert it.Â  See, e. g., Adams v. B & D, Inc., 297 S.C. 416, 419, 377 S.E.2d 315, 317 (1989) (ruling that an affirmative defense not pleaded in the answer or raised before the trial court will not be addressed on appeal).Â  Additionally, Craft failed to raise the estoppel issue to the trial court for a ruling.Â  Accordingly, that issue is not preserved for this courtâ€™s review.Â 
Ulmer v. Ulmer, 369 S.C. 486, ___, 632 S.E.2d 858, 861 (2006) (citing 
In re Michael H., 360 S.C. 540, 546, 602 S.E.2d 729, 732 (2004) (â€œAn issue may not be raised for the first time on appeal.Â  In order to preserve an issue for appeal, it must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€)); Pye v. Estate of Fox, 369 S.C. 555, ___, 633 S.E.2d 505, 510 (2006); Lucas v. Rawl Family Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 359 S.C. 505, 510-11, 598 S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004); Elam v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 23, 602 S.E.2d 772, 779 (2004).Â  Â Furthermore, Craft did not set forth the estoppel argument in his statement of issues on appeal. Â Rule 208(b)(1)(B), SCACR requires an appellantâ€™s initial brief to contain â€œ[a] statement of each of the issues presented for review.â€Â  See State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 693 (2003) (â€œNo point will be considered which is not set forth in the statement of issues on appeal.â€) (citing State v. Bray, 342 S.C. 23, 28, 535 S.E.2d 636, 639, n. 2 (2000)); State v. Prioleau, 345 S.C. 404, 411, 548 S.E.2d 213, 216 (2001); Barnes v. Cohen Dry Wall, Inc., 357 S.C. 280, 287, 592 S.E.2d 311, 314, n. 11 (Ct. App. 2003) (declining to address issues that were not set forth in appellantâ€™s statement of issues on appeal).Â  Luculently, the issue of estoppel is not properly before this court. 
I.Â  UTPA
Craft challenges the trial courtâ€™s ruling in denying his motion for a directed verdict on Wrightâ€™s UTPA cause of action.Â  He contends he was entitled to a directed verdict on the following grounds: 

(A) Damagesâ€”The damages awarded by the jury were improper under the UTPA; Wright suffered no damages; 
(B) Deceptive Actâ€”Wright failed to demonstrate Craftâ€™s conduct was deceptive because Craft did not have a duty to disclose; and 
(C) Craftâ€™s act or practices did not impact the public interest.Â  

In ruling on a motion for directed verdict, the trial court must view the evidence and all its reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party. Long v. Norris & Assocs. Ltd., 342 S.C. 561, 568, 538 S.E.2d 5, 9 (Ct. App. 2000). Â When the evidence yields only one inference, a directed verdict in favor of the moving party is proper.Â  Id.Â  On the other hand, the trial court must deny a motion for a directed verdict when the evidence yields more than one inference or its inference is in doubt. McMillan v. Oconee Memâ€™l Hosp., Inc., 367 S.C. 559, 564, 626 S.E.2d 884, 886 (2006); Bailey v. Segars, 346 S.C. 359, 365, 550 S.E.2d 910, 913 (Ct. App. 2001); Steinke v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing & Regulation, 336 S.C. 373, 386, 520 S.E.2d 142, 148 (1999).Â  If more than one inference can be drawn from the evidence, a jury issue is created and the motion should be denied and the case must be submitted to the jury.Â  Jinks v. Richland County, 355 S.C. 341, 345, 585 S.E.2d 281, 283 (2003); Long, 342 S.C. at 568, 538 S.E.2d at 9; Adams v. G.J. Creel Sons, Inc., 320 S.C. 274, 277, 465 S.E.2d 84, 85 (1995).Â  However, this rule does not authorize the submission of speculative, theoretical, and hypothetical views to the jury.Â  Proctor v. Depâ€™t of Health and Envtl. Control, 368 S.C. 279, 292-93, 628 S.E.2d 496, 503 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  The issue must be submitted to the jury whenever there is material evidence tending to establish the issue in the mind of a reasonable juror. Â The Huffines Co., LLC v. Lockhart, 365 S.C. 178, 188, 617 S.E.2d 125, 130 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  In deciding whether to grant or deny a directed verdict motion, the trial court is concerned only with the existence or nonexistence of evidence. Â Pond Place Partners, Inc. v. Poole, 351 S.C. 1, 15, 567 S.E.2d 881, 888 (Ct. App. 2002); Long, 342 S.C. at 568, 538 S.E.2d at 9.
The evidence in this case must be evaluated in light of the legislative mandate set forth in sections 39-5-10 to -560 of the South Carolina Code (1976 & Supp. 2005). Â The UTPA declares â€œunfair or deceptive acts or practices in the conduct of any trade or commerce . . . unlawful.â€ Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-5-20(a) (1976). Â The terms â€œtradeâ€ and â€œcommerceâ€ â€œinclude the advertising, offering for sale, sale or distribution of any services and any property, tangible or intangible, real, personal or mixed, and any other article, commodity or thing of value wherever situate, and include any trade or commerce directly or indirectly affecting the people of this State.â€ Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-5-10(b) (1976).Â  â€œAn unfair trade practice has been defined as a practice which is offensive to public policy or which is immoral, unethical, or oppressive.â€Â  Wogan v. Kunze, 366 S.C. 583, 606, 623 S.E.2d 107, 120 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing deBondt v. Carlton Motorcars, Inc., 342 S.C. 254, 269, 536 S.E.2d 399, 407 (Ct. App. 2000)). S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 26, 602 S.E.2d 772, 781 (2004); Allstate Ins. Co. v. Durham, 314 S.C. 529, 530, 431 S.E.2d 557, 558 (1993) (footnote omitted). Â â€œA new trial absolute should be granted only if the verdict is so grossly excessive that it shocks the conscience of the court and clearly indicates the amount of the verdict was the â€˜result of caprice, passion, prejudice, partiality, corruption, or other improper motives.â€™ â€ Smalls v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Educ., 339 S.C. 208, 215, 528 S.E.2d 682, 686 (Ct. App. 2000) (citations omitted); Vinson v. Hartley, 324 S.C. 389, 404, 477 S.E.2d 715, 723 (Ct. App. 1996) (citing Cock-N-Bull Steak House, Inc. v. Generali Ins. Co., 321 S.C. 1, 9, 466 S.E.2d 727, 731 (1996)). Â To warrant a new trial, the verdict must be so grossly excessive as to clearly indicate the influence of an improper motive on the jury. Â Welch v. Epstein, 342 S.C. 279, 302, 536 S.E.2d 408, 420 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The failure of the trial judge to grant a new trial absolute in this situation amounts to an abuse of discretion, and on appeal this court will grant a new trial absolute. Stevens, 336 S.C. at 447, 520 S.E.2d at 629 (citing Vinson, 324 S.C. at 404-05, 477 S.E.2d at 723); Allstate Ins. Co., 314 S.C. at 531, 431 S.E.2d at 558.Â  However, â€œ[w]hen a verdict falls within the range of the evidence, the courts will not disturb it on the ground of excessiveness.â€Â  Satcher v. Berry, 299 S.C. 381, 385, 385 S.E.2d 41, 43 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  â€œThe juryâ€™s verdict will not be overturned if any evidence exists that sustains the factual findings implicit in its decision.â€ Smalls, 339 S.C. at 215, 528 S.E.2d at 686.
The trial court, which heard the evidence and is more familiar with the evidentiary atmosphere at trial, possesses a better-informed view of the damages than this court. Â Krepps v. Ausen, 324 S.C. 597, 608, 479 S.E.2d 290, 295-96 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Accordingly, the decision to grant a new trial is left to the sound discretion of the trial court and generally will not be disturbed on appeal. Â Id.Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s findings are wholly unsupported by the evidence or the conclusions reached are controlled by an error of law. Â Id.Â  â€œIn deciding whether to assess error when a new trial motion is
denied, this [c]ourt must consider the testimony and reasonable inferences therefrom in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.â€ Â Welch, 342 S.C. at 302-03, 536 S.E.2d at 420.
The jury awarded damages equal to the actual damages Wright claimed.Â  The verdict is within the range of evidence presented and that evidence sustains the factual findings implicit in the juryâ€™s decision.Â  Accordingly, we give the proper deference to the jury in awarding damages and to the trial court in reviewing that award.Â  
VII.Â  Estoppel
Craft claims Wright should be estopped from alleging damages because Wright stated in a loan application that the Truckâ€™s value was $15,000 to $16,000, while complaining in this action that the Truck has no value.Â  We disagree. 
The â€œ[e]ssential elements of estoppel as related to the party claiming the estoppel are: (1) lack of knowledge and of means of knowledge of truth as to facts in question; (2) reliance upon conduct of the party estopped; and (3) prejudicial change in position.â€Â  Zabinski v. Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 589, 553 S.E.2d 110, 114 (2001).Â  The â€œ[e]lements of equitable estoppel as to the party estopped are: (1) conduct by the party estopped which amounts to a false representation or concealment of material facts; (2) the intention that such conduct shall be acted upon by the other party; and (3) knowledge, actual or constructive, of the true facts.â€Â  Id.Â  Evidence indicates Craft had at least as much, if not more knowledge about the true value of the Truck than Wright did.Â  In addition, no evidence suggests the loan application executed by Wright was intended to induce Craftâ€™s reliance on the information contained in the application.Â  Moreover, Craft did not change his position in reliance on the loan application. Â 
Under the theory of judicial estoppel Craft claims Wright maintained two inconsistent positionsâ€”i. e. in the loan application Wright stated the Truck was worth $15,000 to $16,000 and in the current action he alleges that the Truck is worthless.Â  â€œJudicial estoppel is an equitable concept that prevents a litigant from asserting a position inconsistent with, or in conflict with, one the litigant has previously asserted in the same or related proceeding.â€  Cothran v. Brown,
357 S.C. 210, 215, 592 S.E.2d 629, 631 (2004) (emphasis added).Â  The purpose of the doctrine is to ensure the integrity of the judicial process, not to protect the parties from allegedly dishonest conduct by their adversary. Â Id. (citing Hawkins v. Bruno Yacht Sales, 353 S.C. 31, 42, 577 S.E.2d 202, 208 (2003)).Â  Five elements are required for the application of judicial estoppel:

(1) two inconsistent positions must be taken by the same party or parties in privity with each other;
(2) the two inconsistent positions were both made pursuant to sworn statements;
(3) the positions must be taken in the same or related proceedings involving the same parties in privity with each other;
(4) the inconsistency must be part of an intentional effort to mislead the court; and
(5) the two positions must be totally inconsistent-that is, the truth of one position must necessarily preclude the veracity of the other position.

Quinn v. Sharon Corp., 343 S.C. 411, 422, 540 S.E.2d 474, 480 (Ct. App. 2000) (Anderson, J., concurring in result only) (emphasis added).
Craft urges us to take a broad view of the phrase â€œsame or relatedâ€ but does not explain how the loan application qualifies as a proceeding related to the current action.Â  He cites Hayne Fed. Credit Union v. Bailey, 327 S.C. 242, 489 S.E.2d 472 (1997), and Quinn, 343 S.C. at 414-15, 540 S.E.2d at 476, in support of this broad view.Â  However, neither of these cases supports applying judicial estoppel in the present case.Â  In Hayne, the appellant in a divorce action claimed he had no legal interest in certain property owned by his son.Â  327 S.C. at 252, 489 S.E.2d at 477. Â He later contended he owned certain property by virtue of a resulting trust.Â  Id.Â  The court applied the doctrine of judicial estoppel to bar the appellant from claiming the property.Â  Id. at 252, 489 S.E.2d at 477 (â€œWhen a party has formally asserted a certain version of the facts in litigation, he cannot later change those facts when the initial version no longer suits him.â€).Â  In Quinn, the appellant had previously filed an answer and counterclaim
admitting his daughter owned and operated a corporation and stating that he had no authority to bind the corporation. Â 343 S.C. at 414-15, 540 S.E.2d at 476. Â In another case, the same appellant testified his daughter owned the corporation and denied that he owned any real estate, stocks, bonds, notes, or other valuable property. Â Id. at 415, 540 S.E.2d at 476.Â  Appellant then claimed, in a later action, that he was the sole owner of the corporation.Â  Id.Â  The court held appellantâ€™s later claim was barred by judicial estoppel because it directly contravened his assertions in the prior related litigations.Â  Id.Â Â  The Quinn court announced, Â Â â€œ[w]ere we to allow [appellant] to change his position as to the facts and now claim ownership of the Corporation, â€˜the truth-seeking function of the judicial process [would be] undermined.â€™ â€ Quinn, 343 S.C. at 415, 540 S.E.2d at 476.
Unlike the circumstances in Hayne and Quinn, the loan application in which Wright asserted the Truck had value was not produced in any type of formal proceeding or litigation and was not a sworn statement.Â  Moreover, Craft, though a party to this litigation, was not a party to the loan application. Even broadly interpreting â€œsame or related,â€ the loan application cannot be considered the same or related to the current litigation and judicial estoppel does not apply to bar Wrightâ€™s claim.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, for the foregoing reasons, the trial courtâ€™s rulings are
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

title: James v. SC Employee Insurance Program
description: This appeal arises from a dispute about health insurance coverage under a group plan for state employees and their dependents.  The State of South Carolina Employee Insurance Program appeals an order of the circuit court finding David and Linda James were entitled to coverage for a  DOC Band for their infant daughter on the basis it was a medically necessary device to treat her conditions of plagiocephaly and torticollis.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Linda James and David James, individually and as parents and natural guardians of Meredith James, a minor under the age of 14,
Respondents,
v.
State of South Carolina Employee Insurance Program, [1] 
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4182
Submitted November 1, 2006 â€“ Filed November 27, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Theodore DuBose Willard, Jr., of Columbia, for Appellant.
John Magruder Read, IV, of Greenville, for Respondents.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  This appeal arises from a dispute about health insurance coverage under a group plan for state employees and their dependents.Â  David James, acting on behalf of himself and his wife, Linda (collectively, â€œthe Jamesesâ€), sought pre-authorization for a medical device for their infant daughter, Meredith.Â  Blue Cross Blue Shield of South Carolina (â€œBlue Crossâ€), denied coverage on the basis the device, which is designed to treat a misshaped skull, was not medically necessary as it served only a cosmetic purpose.Â  The Appeals Committee of the State of South Carolina Employee Insurance Program (â€œEIPâ€), upheld the denial of coverage.Â  The circuit court reversed, finding the device was medically necessary and within the scope of the policyâ€™s coverage.Â  We affirm the circuit courtâ€™s ruling.[2]
FACTS
David James was employed by the State of South Carolina, which, through EIP, has established a group health insurance plan (â€œState Health Planâ€) for state employees and their dependents.Â  Blue Cross is responsible for processing the claims.Â  At the time this action arose, James had coverage for himself and his dependents.Â  Â 
The Jamesesâ€™ daughter, Meredith, was born on March 4, 2003.Â  She was diagnosed with plagiocephaly when she was approximately ten and a half months old.Â  According to exhibits included in the record, this term has been generally defined as follows:

Plagiocephaly, which literally translates to â€œoblique head,â€ is a term used to describe asymmetry of the head shape [] when viewed from the top.Â  Late during fetal life, the head may become compressed unevenly in utero . . . .Â  Such inequality of forces may result in asymmetric molding of the head and face.[3]Â  

In addition to restrictive intrauterine positioning, plagiocephaly can develop from such causes as birth trauma, torticollis, and sleeping position.Â  
Meredith was also diagnosed with a condition known as torticollis, or twisted neck syndrome, which refers to the posture that results from the head being tilted or twisted for a variety of reasons.[4]Â  It has been further defined as follows:

Torticollis, or twisted neck, is a condition in which the sternocleidomastoid muscle is shortened or tightened on one side of the neck, causing the head to tilt toward the affected muscle and the head to turn away. This is the most frequent cause of deformational posterior plagiocephaly, which results from progressive occipital flattening when a baby with torticollis is preferentially placed in [a] supine position.[5]Â  

To treat this condition, the Jameses sought pre-authorization from Blue Cross for a Dynamic Orthotic Cranioplasty Band, or DOC Band, for Meredith.Â  A DOC Band is similar to a helmet and is used to correct the shape of an infantâ€™s head.Â  Cranial Technologies, Inc., the supplier, described the device as follows in its documentation requesting pre-authorization approval for Meredith: 

The DOCÂ® Band is an FDA approved medical device for the treatment of deformational plagiocephaly.Â  It is a non-invasive outpatient procedure used for correcting abnormal head shape in infants up to 18 months.Â  The procedure involves making a plaster cast of the infantâ€™s head and custom creating a band which is worn 23 hours a day.Â  The infant is monitored and the band is modified on a weekly or biweekly basis.Â  Average treatment time is 2-4 months.Â Â Â  

The DOC Band is a six-ounce device consisting of an outer plastic shell with a foam lining, and mild pressure is applied to inhibit growth in prominent areas and encourage growth in flat areas.Â  The DOC Band is viable for about two to four months, and some children may require more than one band, depending on the age of the child and the severity of the deformity.Â  A DOC Band costs approximately $3,000.00.Â  The price is an all-inclusive fee that includes fabrication, adjustments to the DOC Band, and all patient visits.Â Â Â  
Blue Cross denied coverage on the basis the treatment was purely for cosmetic purposes and was not medically necessary. Â The Jameses sought review by the Appeals Committee of EIP, which upheld the denial of coverage by letter of February 25, 2005 based on several provisions and exclusions in the State Health Plan.Â  The first provision is found in Article 2 of the State Health Plan, entitled â€œDEFINITIONS,â€ which defines medically necessary as follows:

2.57 Medical Necessity; Medically Necessary or Necessary Service and Supply
A service or supply that: 
A.Â  Is required to identify or treat an illness or injury; and
B.Â  Is prescribed or ordered by a Physician, and
C. Is consistent with the Covered Personâ€™s illness, injury, or condition, and in accordance with proper medical and surgical practices prevailing in the medical specialty or field of medicine at the time rendered; and
D.Â  Is required for reasons other than the convenience of the patient.Â  The fact that a service is prescribed by a Physician does not necessarily mean that such service is Medically Necessary.Â  

Additionally, the Appeals Committee of EIP relied on Article 9, entitled â€œEXCLUSIONS AND LIMITATIONS,â€ which provides in relevant part as follows:

9.1Â  No benefits will be provided under any Article of this Plan for any service, supply or charges for the following:
A.Â  Any service or charge for service which is not Medically Necessary as defined in paragraph 2.57; any service or charge for service which is performed in a more costly setting than that required by a Covered Personâ€™s condition, in which case benefits will be limited to the benefits due had the services been performed in the least costly setting required by the Covered Personâ€™s condition;
Â . . . .
J.Â  Hospital and Physicians services and prescription drugs related to procedures or goods that have primarily cosmetic effects including but not limited to cosmetic surgery, or the complications resulting there from.Â  Cosmetic goods, procedures or surgery shall mean all goods, procedures, and surgical procedures performed to improve appearance or to correct a deformity without restoring a bodily function.Â  In the instances of the following and other procedures which might be considered â€œcosmeticâ€â€”e.g., rhinoplasty (nose), mentoplasty (chin), rhytidoplasty (face lift), glabellar rhytidoplasty, surgical planing (dermabrasion), blepharoplasty (eyelid), mammoplasty (suspension or augmentation), superficial chemosurgery (acid peel of the face) and rhytidectomy (abdomen, legs, hips, or buttocks including lipectomy or adipectomy)â€” benefits may only be provided when the malappearance or deformity was caused by physical trauma, surgery, or congenital anomaly (as opposed to familial characteristics or aging phenomenon) occurring after the Covered Personâ€™s Effective Date of coverage under this Plan or a Predecessor Plan; provided, however, that surgery to correct a cleft palette, or for restoration required because of burn injuries, or other similar procedures performed in stages or after certain growth has been attained, are not excluded because the physical trauma, surgery or congenital anomaly (as opposed to familial characteristics or aging phenomenon), occurred after the Covered Personâ€™s Effective Date of Coverage under this Plan or a Predecessor Plan . . . .Â  [Emphasis added.]Â  Â Â 

The Appeals Committee of EIP concluded the DOC Band claims for Meredith dated February 6, 2004 and July 2, 2004 fell within these contractual exclusions.[6]Â  The Jameses appealed this determination to the circuit court, which reversed, finding the DOC Bands were medically necessary and within the scope of coverage.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Section 1-11-710(C) of the South Carolina Code provides that â€œclaims for benefits under any self-insured plan of insurance offered by the State to state and public school district employees and other eligible
individuals must be resolved by procedures established by the board [South Carolina Budget and Control Board], which shall constitute the exclusive remedy for these claims, subject only to appellate judicial review consistent with the standards provided in Section 1-23-380.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-11-710(C) (2005).Â  
After the exhaustion of administrative remedies, an appeal for review may be made to the circuit court, which sits in an appellate capacity.Â  Under section 1-23-380(A)(6) of the Administrative Procedures Act (â€œAPAâ€), a reviewing court may reverse the decision of an agency upon the grounds, among others, that the decision is â€œaffected by [an] error of lawâ€ or is â€œclearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(d) & (e) (2005).Â  In addition, the decision may be reversed where it is â€œarbitrary or capricious or characterized by [an] abuse of discretion or [a] clearly unwarranted exercise of discretion.â€Â  Id. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(f).
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, EIP contends the circuit court erred in finding the administrative agencyâ€™s decision was clearly erroneous and not supported by substantial evidence.Â  We disagree.
In finding the DOC Bands were medically necessary and within the scope of the State Health Planâ€™s terms of coverage, the circuit court noted that Meredithâ€™s â€œtreating neurosurgeon, Dr. John Johnson[,] stated unequivocally that the application of the DOC Bands were â€˜medically necessaryâ€™ to correct her plagiocephaly.â€[7]Â  The court additionally noted:

The record further reflects that the childâ€™s condition was characterized by deformity of the skull, face and jaw.Â  The records from Dr. Johnson and notes from the Respondentâ€™s own internal Nurse Review both set forth that the treatment prescribed was purposed to remedy in part, â€œmusculoskeletal deformities of skull, face and jawâ€ of the infant.Â  As set forth in the medical research contained within the record, malocclusion of the mandible or jaw is a functional abnormality often associated with this defect and the DOC [B]and is a remedy prescribed to prevent development of this condition where the jaw, face and skull are malformed.Â  

In Bynum v. Cigna Healthcare of North Carolina, Inc., 287 F.3d 305 (4th Cir. 2002), the United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit, upheld an order of the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina requiring coverage for a DOC Band to correct an infantâ€™s skull deformity.Â  Id. at 315.Â  The Fourth Circuit rejected the insurerâ€™s assertion that the DOC Band served only a cosmetic function and was not medically necessary and was, therefore, outside the scope of coverage in a claim governed by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act (â€œERISAâ€).Â  Id. at 314.
The child in question, Katrina Bynum, was diagnosed with plagiocephaly directly related to congenital torticollis, which her treating pediatrician stated â€œis a medical condition[,] not a cosmetic condition.â€Â  Id. at 310.Â  Katrina had flattening on the right side of her head, her right ear was closer to the face than her left ear, and the right side of her head protruded outward greater than the left side.Â  Id. at 309-10 & 310 n.8.Â  The Fourth Circuit found Katrinaâ€™s DOC Band was not cosmetic as it â€œwas not utilized for the sole purpose of providing her with an aesthetically pleasing, symmetrical head shape . . . .â€Â  Id. at 314.Â  â€œInstead, her DOC Procedure constituted treatment for a congenital birth defect and its related symptoms, with the added hope that it might prevent the onset of serious abnormalities associated with her birth defect, such as malocclusion of the mandible.â€Â  Id.Â  The court concluded the insurerâ€™s determination that the DOC Band was purely cosmetic â€œwas objectively unreasonable and not supported by substantial evidence.â€Â  Id.
Â Â 
The court also rejected the argument that the DOC Band was not covered because it was not medically necessary since it was not necessary â€œfor the . . . treatment, cure or relief of a Medical Condition, illness, injury or diseaseâ€ as defined by the health plan.Â  Id. at 315.Â  The court noted that â€œboth of Katrinaâ€™s treating physicians, a pediatrician and a pediatric neurosurgeon, opined that Katrinaâ€™s asymmetrical head shape was a medical condition requiring treatment.Â  And the uncontradicted medical evidence indicates that the appropriate treatment for Katrinaâ€™s medical condition was the DOC Procedure.â€Â  Id. at 315.
The court further concluded that the insurerâ€™s rejection of coverage, whether being based on the lack of medical necessity or on its being excluded as a cosmetic procedure, was not objectively reasonable and constituted an abuse of discretion.Â  Id. Â The court stated that it was â€œleft with the definite and firm conviction that [the insurer] committed a clear error of judgment, and it thereby abused its discretionâ€ in this case.[8]Â  Id.  
We find this reasoning persuasive in the instant appeal and conclude its application is warranted here.Â  Article 9, paragraph J of the State Health Plan policy excludes coverage for procedures or goods that have primarily cosmetic effects, which it defines as follows:Â  â€œCosmetic goods, procedures or surgery shall mean all goods, procedures, and surgical procedures performed to improve appearance or to correct a deformity without restoring a bodily function.â€Â  Even where items are arguably cosmetic, however, benefits â€œmay . . . be provided when the malappearance or deformity was caused by physical trauma, surgery, or congenital anomaly . . . .â€Â  Â Â 
Before Meredith was two months old, the Jameses noticed her eyes and ears did not look symmetrical.Â  One of her ears was a little smaller than the other and her eyes appeared to be of dissimilar size.Â  Her pediatrician at the time, Dr. Raymond Flanders, told them it could be the orbital bones that made the eyes appear different.Â Â Â  
Meredith was ultimately diagnosed at ten and one-half months with plagiocephaly and torticollis.Â  At that point Meredith was seen by Dr. John Johnson, a neurosurgeon with the Southeastern Neurological and Spine Institute, who found Meredith had positional plagiocephaly.Â  Dr. Johnson wrote a prescription for a cranial molding device, the DOC Band, on February 2, 2004.Â  
Dr. Johnson, as Meredithâ€™s treating neurosurgeon, stated in a letter dated February 2, 2004, that Meredith was â€œfound to have a form of positional cranial deformity known as plagiocephaly.Â  This particular deformity may be corrected by the use of a cranial helm[e]t.Â  This device is used to [reshape] the distorted head shape of an infant so that hopefully surgery is avoided.Â  I strongly feel that this device is medically necessary for the treatment of this child.â€[9]Â  
As noted by the circuit court, â€œthe only physician who personally examined and treated the infant child stated unequivocally that the treatment was medically necessary.â€Â  Even the peer review analysis conducted at the request of Blue Cross noted that the DOC Band had improved not only â€œthe shape of the patientâ€™s headâ€ but also â€œthe degree of torticollisâ€ (twisted neck syndrome).Â  Cranial Technologies, the company producing the DOC Band, opined that use of the DOC Band â€œresults in normal to near normal head shape.Â  If left untreated, the infant can have persistent facial asymmetry, which can affect mandibular mechanics, jaw function, airway and orbital alignment.Â  For this reason, the DOC Band is deemed a medical necessity.â€Â  
The Jameses point out that the American Medical Association (â€œAMAâ€) has issued Resolution 119 (I-97), which states the AMA is aware that â€œ[i]nsurance companies . . . are increasingly denying insurance coverage for treatment of childrenâ€™s deformities, disfigurement and congenital defects, claiming that these services are non-functional and thus considered â€˜cosmeticâ€™ in nature and therefore declared a non-covered disorder.â€Â  See â€œCoverage of Childrenâ€™s Deformities, Disfigurement and Congenital Defects,â€ American Medical Association, Resolution 119 (I-97) <www.ama-assn.org; www.cappskids.org/res119.pdf>.Â  Resolution 119 affirmatively declares, however, the AMAâ€™s position is that correction of these facial anomalies is not cosmetic because it is performed on abnormal structures to restore them to a more normal state; further, correction is generally to improve function, although it may also be done to approximate a normal appearance.Â  Id.Â  The AMA stated â€œ[c]hildren who do not have birth defects and facial anomalies repaired face long-term physical and psychological injuries.â€Â  Id.Â  The AMA noted at least twelve states had passed legislation requiring insurance coverage for childrenâ€™s deformities or craniofacial surgery.Â  Id.
The AMA has also issued AMA Policy H-185.967, which declares â€œthat treatment of a minor childâ€™s congenital or developmental deformity or disorder due to trauma or malignant disease should be covered by all insurersâ€ and â€œshall include treatment which, in the opinion of the treating physician, is medically necessary to return the patient to a more normal appearance . . . .â€Â  See â€œCoverage of Childrenâ€™s Deformities, Disfigurement and Congenital Defects,â€ American Medical Association, AMA Policy H-185.967 <www.ama-assn.org/ad-com/polfind/hlth-ethics.pdf>.Â  
We find EIPâ€™s assertion that coverage should be denied based on its averment that Meredith did not currently have severe mandible or other problems requiring surgery to be unpersuasive.Â  The position of the treating physician was that treatment would prevent the development of these problems and obviate the need for surgery.Â  In our view, it would not be reasonable to require a patient to delay medically-recognized, viable treatments until a problem becomes more severe before coverage applies.Â  
Further, we agree with the circuit court that, considering the record as a whole, reasonable minds would conclude treatment in this case is not primarily cosmetic, but rather, it does affect the functioning of the patient and it is medically necessary.Â  Cf. Baggott v. S. Music, Inc., 330 S.C. 1, 5-6, 496 S.E.2d 852, 854-55 (1998) (finding substantial evidence is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the agencyâ€™s conclusion; the supreme court held substantial evidence did not support the agencyâ€™s determination to deny coverage because reasonable minds would conclude the claimantâ€™s injury did arise out of and in the scope of his employment).Â  
Accordingly, we affirm the order of the circuit court finding the Jamesesâ€™ claim for insurance benefits relating to the DOC Band procedures should be approved.
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We note the defendant in this action was previously misnamed in the pleadings as Blue Cross Blue Shield of South Carolina; however, the circuit court, with the partiesâ€™ consent, â€œORDERED, ADJUDGED and DECREED, that the pleadings be amended to reflect that the State of South Carolina Employee Insurance Program [is] the [Defendant] in this action . . . .â€Â  Accordingly, we have made this amendment in the caption for this appeal.Â Â  Â 
[2] Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3]Â  This definition appears in materials included in the record on â€œTorticollis and Related Issuesâ€ distributed by Dr. John M. Graham, Jr., of the Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, excerpted from Smithâ€™s Recognizable Pattern of Human Deformation, 3rd Edition, W.B. Saunders Publishing Company, Philadelphia PA, 2002.Â  See also Taberâ€™s Cyclopedic Medical Dictionary 1519 (17th ed. 1993) (defining plagiocephaly as â€œ[m]alformation of the skull producing the appearance of a twisted and lopsided headâ€).Â Â Â  Â 
[4] Â This definition appears in the article on â€œTorticollis and Related Issuesâ€ excerpted from Smithâ€™s Recognizable Pattern of Human Deformation and distributed by Dr. John M. Graham, Jr. of Cedars-Sinai Medical Center.Â  See also Taberâ€™s Cyclopedic Medical Dictionary 2012 (17th ed. 1993) (discussing torticollis and its causes). 
[5]Â  This information is from the article on â€œTorticollis and Related Issues.â€Â
